talk.start.para: - Honourable senators, I have to announce that the President, Senator the Hon. Sir Magnus Cormack, is unable to attend the sitting of the Senate this day. In accordance with standing order 29 the Chairman of Committees, Senator Prowse, will take the Chair as Deputy President.

speech.para: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Prowse) thereupon took the Chair, and read prayers.

debate.para: Communications Tower on Black Mountain

talk.start.para: - I present the following petition:

quote.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Sena le in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

item.para: Thai the Australian Post Office proposes to construct a 640ft high solid concrete tower, housing radiotelephony-television transmission facilities, on Black Mountain in Canberra.
That in the opinion of many responsible citizens such a tower would seriously impair the beauty of this city and is likely to lessen the value of the Black Mountain Flora and Fauna Reserve.

That requests from residents of Canberra, and their Parliamentary representative, for information on the technical considerations supposedly favouring a solid tower have been refused by the Australian Post Office.

quote.para: Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should, through its Standing Committee on the Social Environment, examine whether construction of a tower of this nature on Black Mountain is in the public interest, having particular regard to the need to preserve the beauty and environmental quality of the National Capital.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

speech.para: Petition received and read.

talk.start.para: - I present the following petition:

quote.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of the Division of the Australian Capital Territory respectfully showeth:
That they have no objection to the Aboriginal Embassy being on the lawns outside Parliament House.
That they believe that the Aborigines in common with all other Australian citizens, have a right to assemble in any peaceful manner of their own choice.
And that they would object to any law that would make their being there illegal.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government does not enact any law that would detract from or hinder the rights of the Aborigines to be there outside Parliament House.

And further that the Government instructs its officers not to interfere with the Aborigines who are peacefully assembled outside Parliament House. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

speech.para: Petition received and read.

talk.start.para: - My question is addressed to the Minister for Health. A few minutes ago the Prime Minister stated that the Minister for Health would announce shortly the terms of a reference of doctors' fees to arbitration. Will the Minister tell us when he expects to be able to announce the name of the arbitrator and the terms of reference? Can he tell us also how the Government proposes to ensure that the doctors abide by any award which may be made by the arbitrator? Is it intended thai there be legislation on the matter? If not, what other means has the Government in mind to ensure observance of the decision?

speech.para: It is true that this morning the Government took a decision to put to arbitration the question of fees for items 1 and 4 in the medical benefit, schedule, that is for surgery consultations and home visits - by general practitioners in New South Wales. The decision follows the widespread nonobservance of common fees for those items by general practitioners in that State. During the luncheon period I informed the Federal President of the Australian Medical Association, as was proper, of the Government's decision taken late this morning. The details and the form and structure of the arbitration procedures are being examined urgently. I can assure the Senate that I will make a public announcement as quickly as possible.

Senator Murphyrather suggested that I should announce quickly who the arbitrator will be and what the terms of reference will be. I know he will appreciate that the decision about the broad principle was taken only this morning and I have the responsibility put upon me to implement it. 1 give an assurance that as quickly as possible I will make a public statement about the terms of reference and who the arbitrator will be. J think everybody would agree that it would be improper for me to make comments before the decisions and announcements are made. As for the matter of enforcement, I think it is rather too early to ask such a question before even the judge, or whoever it may be, is appointed. No doubt I will be asked by the Press and radio stations to make statements or to go on the air in advance of the decisions being made. Honourable senators may rest assured that I will not be making statements until these matters are resolved. All I can say is that I will be dealing with these matters today and possibly into tomorrow - J do not know yet. As soon as they are resolved I would hope to make a statement in the Senate.

talk.start.para: - My question also is directed to the Minister for Health. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to reports that the amoeba responsible for amoebic meningitis has been found in piped water supplies in Adelaide as well as in northern and other parts of South Australia? Has his Department received any official reports on this development? If so, will his Department confer with other related Commonwealth and State establishments in an investigation of all phases of the movement and management of River Murray water? Has the Minister noted also that the South Australian Director-General of Health has said that the amoeba was quite widespread? Will he, not only as the Minister for Health but also as the representative of the Prime Minister in this place, note again the conclusions and recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Water Pollution and press for some national approach to this serious matter?

speech.para: I have seen the newspaper reports referred to by the honourable senator, although no official communication has been sent to me about the amoebic meningitis which was detected. A long time ago I was familiar with amoebic conditions and learnt during the war what effect they can have. The

South Australian authorities have responsibility in this matter. Should they be of the opinion that the medical implications need to be considered at national level, 1 would expect them lo raise the matter with the National Health and Medical Research Council, which is a special body in which (he States and the Commonwealth have direct communication and through which they have direct links. My Department has no responsibility for water supplies from the River Murray. I understand that the report of the Senate Select Committee on Water Pollution is at present under consideration by my colleague the Minister for National Development. To that extent it is currently under examination. However, I repeat that if the South Australian Government feels that the matter referred to by the honourable senator is a national matter; as distinct from one which comes within its own sovereignty, ti has access to the National Health and Medical Research Council, of which it is virtually a constituent member, or it may follow the traditional form of making representations through the Premier to the Prime Minister.

talk.start.para: - I address a question to the Minister for Civil Aviation. Is it proposed to provide new airport facilities at Eagle Farm Airport in Brisbane? Will these facilities be on the site of the present facilities or are they to be relocated?

- Previously I referred to the fact that the Prime Minister and the Premier of Queensland had made a joint statement about development proposals and plans for Eagle Farm airport in Brisbane. The statement indicated quite clearly that the runway system should move into the north east, which inevitably will mean in due course a relocation of the facilities in which the honourable senator is interested. I shall obtain a copy of the statement for the honourable senator and make it available to him.

- I address a question to the Minister for Health. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the published allegation that a former GovernorGeneral of Australia, Lord De L'Isle, transported a dog from Australia to Papua New Guinea and back to Australia? ls there any truth in this allegation and, if so, what were the circumstances?

speech.para: I have seen the report and information has been sought in relation to it. I am able to inform the Senate that, to the best of my knowledge based on information that I have been able to acquire, there is no truth whatever in the story which relates to an incident which was alleged to have occurred in 1963. As a result of inquiries made by my Department we have been informed that there is no truth in the story.

talk.start.para: - My question also is addressed to the Minister for Health. Now that the Department of Health has taken belated action on the drug imipramine by sending telegrams to doctors, can the Minister explain to the Senate whether Dr McBride is the only doctor in Australia who is keeping an effective surveillance over drugs such as imipramine and thalidomide? What system is used by the Federal Department of Health to prevent such drugs being prescribed? If research in Great Britain 10 years ago showed that imipramine was harmful to a foetus, why were warnings nol prominently displayed on containers instead of on loose pamphlets? Finally, is the Minister satisfied with the present, system and, if not, what steps are being taken to make it effective?

speech.para: This matter is tremendously important. I do not want to say anything which would detract in any way from the world renown and recognition of Dr McBride. I want to be seen and heard to say that at the outset. T may take a little longer than I normally lake answering questions in replying on this matter because it is of tremendous importance. 1 should like to state the history of this matter as I have seen it and as I have become involved with it since 1 left here late last week, lt is trite that a letter dated 17th February 1972 was sent by Dr McBride to the Director-General of the Department of Health. My information is that -the letter arrived on 21st or 22nd February. The letter indicated that he was concerned that, what is known as Tofranil, that is imipramine.. could cause limb deformation if ingested in early pregnancy. The letter did not contain any reference to knowledge by Dr McBride of any actual cases where there may have been a link between imipramine and limb deformation. lt was not written in the context of urgency in that sense at all.

The letter was drawn to the attention of the Australian Drug Reaction Advisory Committee at its meeting on Friday, 25th February. On Saturday, 26th February, a Dr Winton, editor of the "Medical Journal of Australia" mentioned informally to Dr Walsche, who is an officer of my Department and Secretary of the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee that a short statement by Dr McBride implicating imipramine as a possible cause of congenital abnormalities would be published in the 4th March issue of the Journal. I would like to repeat that the information would be published in the 4th March issue of the Journal. In view of the concern arising out of the Press statement by Dr McBride on Thursday, 2nd March - which was las/ Thursday - I requested the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee to consider the matter at its meeting on Friday, 3rd March, which was Kie next day. After that meeting, the Chairman of the Committee. Sir William Morrow, issued a statement to the Press. Sir William Morrow also was interviewed by radio and television news media after the meeting which, as .1 have said, was held on 3rd March, last Friday.

On the morning of Saturday, 4th March - 1 was at a conference of Health Ministers on the earlier days - following the conclusion of the Health Ministers conference on Friday night, I had discussions with the Director-General of Health. Following upon that, 1 personally spoke by telephone to Dr T. I. Robertson, Chairman of the Adverse Drug Reactions Advisory Sub-committee of the Drug Evaluation Committee and told him of my desire that the Sub-committee meeting should be held as soon as possible to consider imipramine. 1 had further discussions with the Director-General on Sunday, again, last week - by which time it had emerged that the Adverse Drug Reactions Advisory Subcommittee could not consider this matter before Wednesday, that is, tomorrow, 8th

March, mainly because Dr McBride had indicated that he was not in a position to provide the necessary information on imipramine before that date. That was the earliest date on which Dr McBride said he was able to meet the Committee.

When it become clear that the meeting could not be held until tomorrow, I conferred with the Director-General on what immediate steps could be taken. The Director-General arranged an urgent meeting on Sunday night last between the Chairman of the Drug Evaluation Committee, Sir William Morrow, the Chairman of the Adverse Drug Reactions Advisory Subcommittee, Dr Robertson, and himself. When the Director-General reported to me the discussion which had taken place at that meeting, I decided that a telegram should be forwarded by the DirectorGeneral to every medical practitioner in Australia. On Monday - yesterday - such telegrams were forwarded. The telegrams read as follows:

quote.para: Pending Australian Drug Evaluation Committee's clarification of current issue associating imipramine with foetal abnormalities it is strongly recommended that imipramine not be prescribed for females in child-bearing age. lt will be seen that, far from being dilatory in dealing with this matter, my Department and I obviously acted with the greatest possible speed in dealing with the imipramine question. When it became clear that Dr McBride had some relevant facts to offer on this matter, rather than what might be described as a general indication of doubt as contained in his letter of 17th February, every step that could have been taken in this respect was taken. Incidentally, 1 should mention that Australia is ahead of the whole world in taking action concerning this drug. For example, although the United States has some excellent systems for dealing with adverse drug reactions, the health authorities in that country are seeking information from Australia on (he imipramine question. It is a matter that we must treat very seriously. I assure the Senate that everything possible is being done. The Committee will meet tomorrow. Naturally I will be given a report immediately it concludes its deliberations. Any action it recommends should be taken or it is necessary to take after that meeting will be taken.

talker.party: IND; AP from Aug. 1969; IND from Jan. 1970
talker.name: TURNBULL, Reginald
Senator TURNBULL

talk.start.para: - I wish to ask a question of the Minister for Health. 1 was very interested to hear that an arbitrator is to be appointed in regard to the determination of doctors' fees, but what assurance does the Australian Medical Association have that the Government will abide by the decision of the arbitrator if he finds that fees should be increased? I ask that question because when an arbitrator found that chemists should receive a higher payment the Commonwealth Government immediately said that it did not agree with the arbitrator's decision. I point out that although, I think, 5 years have elapsed the dispute with the chemists still has not been settled. That is why I have asked what will happen when the decision of the arbitrator is given in relation to fees charged by the medical profession?

- I have no worries or doubts in my mind as to what the Government will do as a consequence of what an arbitrator may decide. I do not want to link 'his matter with what happened in relation to the pharmaceutical industry because that is another question altogether. In fairness to all concerned I think I should repeat the point I made to Senator Murphy that whilst we are in the critical situation of setting up this arbitration procedure, 1 do not think (hat I can in all conscience answer questions on this matter.

- My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. 1 preface, it by reminding him that on 22nd February, at question time, he invited me to produce the name of a manufacturer who is using the changeover to the metric system of measuring to reduce the quantities and increase the prices of his product. I also remind the Minister that he promised to conduct an investigation if I produced the name of the manufacturer and the product. I now produce for the Minister a 2-litre container of orange juice manufactured by Sunburst Foods Pty Ltd which lakes the place of a half-gallon container - -the one I hold in my hand was not produced by the same manufacturer but it is almost identical with the container previously used by that manufacturer - and which is sold at the same price although it contains 10 fluid ounces less. I ask: What action will the Minister lake to prevent profiteering by this company and other manufacturers in the changeover to the metric system of measuring?

- 1 did make a promise that 1 would investigate any such matter if I were given the particulars. However, J am rather disappointed thai they have been given in the Senate. If they had been given to me in the normal way 1 could have dealt with them, but il is a rather dangerous practice to be unilaterally declaring situations to exist before they are proven to exist. But I will adhere to the promise I made to have this matter investigated. I would ask the honourable senator whether, after this matter has been dealt with, he will agree to sharing the contents of these containers with those honourable senators who wish to have a sip.

- 1 direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Labour and National Service. Following the transport workers strike last Friday and the banning of refuelling services at Tullamarine Airport, which resulted in the disruption of domestic air services throughout Australia, I ask: Has the Minister any estimate of the cost to the airlines, industry and commerce - which would not take account, of course, of the inconvenience caused to so many people - of this strike? ls the Minister able to say whether this strike was due to demarcation issues between the 2 trade unions involved? If it was, what steps will the Minister take to prevent this type of guerilla strike over domestic issues between trade unions through jealousies and attempted domination by trade union leaders over others?

- 1 regret thai I cannot give the honourable senator an estimate of the cost of this dispute, although to date it has caused a delay of some 3 hours in aircraft operations. It does represent a demarcation dispute between the transport and engineering unions. The matter has been before a Conciliation Commissioner this morning and certain discus sions have taken place which I feel it inappropriate to detail. Elements of the dispute still exist inasmuch as engineers refuse to train the transport workers to do the work that the transport workers wish to take over. Suggestions have been made that the Australian Council of Trade Unions should determine this demarcation dispute. The threat by the Transport Workers Union remains that if settlement is not reached by I think, next Friday another 3-days disruption will occur.

- ls the Minister for Health aware that the former Prime Minister, the Rt Hon. J. G. Gorton, gave an undertaking during the general election campaign of 1969 and again during the Senate election campaign of 1970 that increased payments would be made to regular contributors to health insurance organisations who were inmates of nursing homes and who were receiving intensive care. If this is so, can the Minister advise the Senate when these promises will be honoured?

speech.para: I do not know that 1 am completely conversant with the implications of the question. The Government has made a decision to make increased payments in respect of nursing home care. When I became Minister for Health, I was asked in relation to the problems of nursing homes-

talk.start.para: - We are talking about health.

speech.para: The honourable senator asked about nursing homes. The situation now in nursing homes is that intensive care patients receive $6.50 a day, provided they are classified as intensive care cases, and for ordinary cases receive $3.50. This represents a significant increase.

talk.start.para: - Do not forget that nursing home costs have increased also.

- Do not try to move away from the question. The honourable senator can reframe his question if he wishes. In the case of nursing homes, the Government has acted as I have stated and has received high praise from all over Australia for its action.
- The Minister obviously did not hear my question.

- I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry whether he is concerned about the possible effect on established primary industries of the manufacture and sale of synthetic products which are sold under false labelling as being food which is regularly and confidently consumed by the Australian public. I refer in particular to meat and to milk. As no statement of value has been made either by the Department of Primary Industry or other interested departments as to a possible method of controlling such manufacture, will the Minister arrange for officers of the Department to confer with officers of the AttorneyGeneral's Department as to the possible effect of the recent High Court decision in the case of SOS (Mowbray Heights) Pty Ltd v. Mead with a view to making a statement to the Senate as to the ability which now rests with State governments to control the sale of such substitute products?

- A number of statements have been made by leading personnel in primary industry organisations pointing out the inroads that synthetic meat could make into the meat industry. I think a statement was made by the chairman of the Australian Meat Board early last year on this matter. He pointed out to the meat industry that it would have to deliver the goods and at the same time watch the inroads that synthetic meat could make into the industry. This matter has been raised on several occasions at meetings of the Australian Agricultural Council. The Minister for Primary Industry has written to each State government pointing out that the provisions of labelling come within their jurisdiction and asking each State government to examine its labelling legislation to ensure that synthetic meats are clearly labelled. I am not sure of the legal position but I shall certainly refer the honourable senator's question to the Minister for Primary Industry. If he has any further information, I will give it to the honourable senator.

subdebate.1.para: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Prowse) - I understand Senator Poyser is desirous of asking a supplementary question.

talk.start.para: - I point out that I asked a question about increased payments to be made by health insurance organisations to certain contributors. The increase was promised by the former Prime Minister. Can the Minister for Health now enlighten me about the proposed increase?

- The question is related to payments to certain contributors by health insurance organisations. 1 do not walk away from it. Senator Poyser has been gracious enough to Jet me have a copy of the question. I certainly will respond to it tomorrow.

- I ask a question of the Minister for Civil Aviation. As he has informed me that at the Eagle Farm Airport there will be a relocation of facilities, can he explain why Trans-Australia Airlines is reported to be spending Sim on rebuilding its terminal when, presumably, the rebuilt premises will soon be abandoned in the process of relocating aircraft terminals?

- It will be some time before the facilities are fully relocated. As honourable senators are well aware the Trans-Australia Airlines terminal was burnt out. Arrangements are being made for the provision of a building adequate for the purpose for the time that it will be needed and one that can be used for another purpose in its present site or relocated where the new facilities will be erected.

- I direct to the Minister for Health a question which refers to the use of the drug imipramine. In view of the present concern following the disclosure of hazards associated with the use of imipramine, will the Minister make a statement to the Senate on the procedures operating in Australia for drug evaluation, including the Australian testing of drugs and the international exchange of information about drugs, with a view to reassuring the community that the maximum precautions are being taken? Is there any international arrangement in existence through the World Health Organisation regarding drug evaluation? Will the Australian Government, as a member of the United Nations, initiate action to create an international clearing house for drug acceptability so that world knowledge and experience may be pooled?

speech.para: The question is a comprehensive one. .1 shall be happy to respond to it. The circumstances which prompted the asking of the question are sad. I shall be happy to give the background of the work of the Drug Evaluation Committee and its subcommittees. It is an interesting fact that Australia has felt obliged to send and has sent out signals on this issue, including one to the World Health Organisation. There are telephone conversations and communications passing between Australia and other nations about it. I would be perfectly willing to give a detailed reply. Drug evaluation is a world problem. I saw a Press release to the effect that approximately 2 million people in the United Kingdom have been users of the drug imipramine over a period of years. Primarily it is an anti-depressant drug. T will respond to the question and will get a broad outline of what is done in Australia and of our relations with other countries in this field.

I have given a picture of what happened between last Thursday and today in relation to the drug as it concerns my Department. I have arranged with the Pharmacy Guild of Australia that women of child bearing age who bring to chemists prescriptions for imipramine written before 6th March be advised by the pharmacist to see their prescribing doctor. This is one further step that has been taken. The situation is a holding one. We do not want to put fear and distress into any more minds than we can because tomorrow is an important day in the examination of the drug. I feel bound to say that on Sunday night I had a conversation with Dr McBride, and he paid me the courtesy of talking to me in my office on Monday. He will get all the co-operation that is humanly possible to give to try to assess the problems. He is very careful about what he says. He is very fair about the concern he has.

talk.start.para: - He is a very dedicated man.

speech.para: He is a very dedicated man. He is a world figure. He will be talking to the Adverse Drug Reactions Sub-committee tomorrow. Incidentally, the meeting tomorrow has been enlarged to bring in some other people, particularly in the field of clinical pharmacology. So, the Sub-committee meeting tomorrow will be a meeting of some of the best, if not the best, people in Australia to discuss this matter.

talk.start.para: - Does the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry know whether any investigation has been made as to the suitability of Tasmania for the production of carpet wool? Is it not correct that Tasmania is suitable, from the standpoint of climate and in other respects, for such production?

- 1 have no doubt that Tasmania is suitable for strong wool production; but whether it produces enough wool of this type at the present time or would do so in the immediate future 1 do not know. 1 told Senator Poke the other day, in answer to a question, that I would have investigations made into this matter. I will do that. When I receive the answer, if Senator Poke does nol mind I will let Senator Lillico have a copy of it.

speech.para: My question, which is directed to the Minister for Health, follows the one asked of him by Senator Murphy and the answer given by him. Does he remember his predecessor Senator Greenwood stating as Minister for Health, in a ministerial statement in the Senate on 7th May 1971 announcing increases in medical and hospital insurance contribution rates, that the new most common fees for general practitioner surgery consultations and home visits will apply for a 2-year period from 1st July 1971 to 30th June 1973 and any increase in fees for other medical services before the end of that period will be based on a proper study of available information? Because the arbitration to which the Minister has made reference today will bo in respect of general practitioner services concerning consultations and home visitations, do I take it that the undertaking given to the Parliament and the Australian people on 7th May 1971 has now gone by the board so far as members of the Australian public generally are concerned, and that the Government is shown to be bending over backwards to help the genera! practitioners at the expense of the Australian public?

talk.start.para: - That is a quite erroneous assumption. The question impinges upon the terms of reference which have yet to be announced. To that extent I do not want to be drawn on something which I. am not yet in a position to announce. But what Senator Greenwood said was true and is still true. This is a reference in relation to New South Wales. lt is not suggested that as a result of it there will be a unilateral decision-
- But New South Wales is part of Australia.

speech.para: Yes, I know. The honourable senator has asked his question. He should not try to hedge the answer. I am giving it, not he. The fact of the matter is that the common fee concept is based on a 2-year cycle which is not due to end until 30th June 1973. So, what the honourable senator says is true and what Senator Greenwood said is true, lt certainly is not the intention that any reference in relation to items 1 and 4 of the schedule for general practitioners should create a situation in which New South Wales would have a different set of rules from any other State.

talk.start.para: - My question is addressed to the Minister for Health. Is it a fact that since March 1961 the only alteration to the chemists' professional fee for dispensing national health scheme prescriptions has been a 2c increase granted in 1970? ls he aware that pharmacists are considering withdrawing their services from the national health scheme unless the present system of fixing fees is altered? As the public would suffer the consequences of such action, will he consider establishing an independent tribunal to determine chemists' fees, and remove the increasing dissatisfaction and bitterness in pharmacy?

- It is ironical that at a time when there are some problems in relation to increased medical fees a question is directed to me which has an implication of a sort of advocacy of increased pharmaceutical fees. But be that as it may. I issued a Press statement on this matter following a statement made by the President of the Pharmaceutical Guild of Australia. Also an anonymous document floated around which was a very naughty document. But I made a Press statement in response to the President's letter. I am sure that all honourable senators would have a copy of it in their boxes. I pointed out in that statement that following the last increase given to the pharmacists an offer was made of a survey of fees. Not only was the offer of a survey made but also - and this is in my Press release - an offer was made of retrospectivity in respect of any increase decided upon. In truth, that is as far as the situation has gone. The Commonwealth has offered to make a survey in relation to the cost of medicines and other things which are provided under the National Health Act. The members of the Guild are not prepared to accept the survey. They want another method.

speech.para: I feel bound to say that I am aware that a number of pharmacists have been interviewing honourable senators. I think that the Federal President, if he is not in the building now, will be here tonight to speak to other people. Also I think I am bound to say that I had a discussion with the Federal President in my office in this building last Wednesday. He and I sat around the table trying to find some formula for a solution to this matter. I do not want to prejudice any efforts being made by him, his Guild and myself as the Minister for Health representing the Commonwealth.

I turn to the matter of arbitration. Originally at the invitation of the Guild a body was set up. It provides a membership of 8 people, 4 nominated by the Guild and 4 nominated by the Government. The Guild requested an independent chairman and the Government provided one in the person of Sir Walter Scott. There has been some criticism of that situation too. But if honourable senators have not already heard that no doubt they will today or tomorrow. I have to be completely fair and say that as late as last Wednesday morning I had a conference with the President of the Guild. In fact, in the last few hours we have sought the co-operation of the Guild in the other matter which has been raised. This has been quickly and readily given. I believe that it is still possible to find some solution which will ultimately resolve the deadlock which we have. I repeat that the deadlock arises from the fact that the Government has offered a survey under conditions which the Guild does not find acceptable and the Guild has offered an examination which is not acceptable to the Government. The sooner we can get that deadlock resolved the happier everybody will be.

talk.start.para: - I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Labour and National Service whether he has read a reported statement by the South Australian Minister of Lands in which he alleges that the Commonwealth Department of Labour and National Service has failed to register Aborigines in remote areas in South Australia for unemployment benefit? Will the Minister ask his colleague to investigate this statement to see whether the remarks of the Minister in South Australia have been taken out of context? Can the Minister inform the Senate, firstly, whose responsibility it is to register Aborigines as unemployed; secondly, what facilities are available to Aborigines for this purpose in remote areas, and thirdly, whether provision is made or could bc made for welfare officers or social workers to act as agents for Aborigines to see that they are recorded with the Department as unemployed?

- I am grateful to the honourable senator for drawing my attention to this matter. I have not seen the South Australian Minister's statement, nor am I aware of the other matters the honourable senator has raised. As the question relates to Aborigines it will necessitate reference to the Minister for Labour and National Service and the Minister whose special responsibility Aborigines are. I will refer the question to the appropriate Ministers and obtain a written answer for the honourable senator.

- 1 ask the Minister for Health: Is the legal growing of opium poppies in Tasmania under the control of the Department of Customs and Excise? Docs the Department of Health have as the Deputy Director of Health resident in Tasmania a medical practitioner? Is the Deputy Director assisted by a qualified pharmacist? If the Department of Health has on its staff in Tasmania a qualified doctor and a pharmacist could not such personnel provide all necessary information on poppy growing? If so, why did 3 Second Division officers of the Department of Health in January this year journey to Tasmania to inspect poppy growing? What was the cost of the visit of the 3 officers? If the purpose of the visit was not to give the 3 Second Division officers a holiday at Commonwealth expense, what was the purpose?

speech.para: Sena;or Sir KENNETH ANDERSON - First of all 1 deprecate any suggestion of impropriety which this question carries, lt suggests impropriety against members of the Public Service who cannot defend themselves because the question is asked in this place, and 1 will not have a bar of it. As to the substance of the question, I recall from my own knowledge when T was Minister for Customs and Excise that the growing of opium poppies is under the control of the Department of Customs and Excise. I have not been briefed in relation to the link between this matter and my present department. I will obtain the information and supply it to the Senate tomorrow. I conclude on this note: Accepting that the 3 officers did go to Tasmania - I do not challenge it for a moment and 1 put aside the honourable senator's implications related to this aspect of the question - J would say that whatever was the cost of sending them to make certain that everything was being done to protect the nation against illegal use of poppy it would be a completely justified expenditure.

talk.start.para: - But they have no control over it.

speech.para: I was Minister for Customs and Excise from 1964 to 1967 and I am aware, contrary to what Senator Cavanagh indicated, that the Department has an all over control in relation to this matter. There would not be a department - and 1 think there are 27 ministries-

talk.start.para: - Too many.

speech.para: Senator Sir KENNETHANDERSON - That is another matter. Let us keep to the point. The fact is that there would not be a department which does not have some inter-relationship with another department. Some fields impinge not on one department but on 4 or 5 departments. Every day, or at any rate, every week, there are interdepartmental meetings associated with the administration of something which would involve the special interest of 4, 5 or even 6 departments. One only has to think of the Department of the Interior which, on a broad canvas, is responsible for the Northern Territory. Senator Cavanagh is interjecting, lt is all right to take a swing at people who cannot defend themselves but when 1 want to put things on the line he does not like it and wants to interrupt. subdebateinfo.title: SEMINAR ON DRUGS AND THE MASS MEDIA

talk.start.para: - Has the Minister for Health seen a report in the Canberra Courier' of Thursday, 2nd March, in which it is claimed that at a seminar on Drugs and the Mass Media', held in

speech.para: Canberra on the previous weekend, the talks by experts did little but cause confusion and that discussion of responsible and irresponsible reporting of drug cases was so basic that it was irritating? In view of this report, does the Minister consider that the expense involved in staging this seminar was justified?

The answer to the last part of the question is that the expenditure was completely justified. To the extent that we can get the widest possible publicity of the terrible consequences of drug taking, with special reference to the young, the expenditure is justified. In asking his question the honourable senator has repeated what some person has chosen to write. That is fair enough, I suppose. 1 do nol suppose any of us has been to a seminar of which someone did not say that in his judgment nothing came out of it or not enough came out of it. It is a personal opinion. Everybody is entitled to an opinion. But it is a most unwise person who opens his mouth and swallows everything that he reads. I did not attend this seminar. The Minister assisting the Miniser for Health, who was the Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Drug Trafficking and Drug Abuse, was present and I am told that he did a magnificent job. I, as Minister, am proud of the report that I received on the way in which he de-fused certain things that happened there.

It is not unique for people, to say that they did not get the lift that they sought from a certain activity. This is human nature, is it not? That situation arises here when somebody makes a magnificent speech and somebody else thinks that it was a horror. The truth of the matter is that even I, although I try to be most patient, get a bit excited, as honourable senators saw today. This is in the nature of human beings. But let us not move away from the cardinal factor in relation to this matter. The purpose of a seminar such as that which was held is to obtain the widest possible coverage through the media, and by other means, of drug addiction. Even if the percentage of success from that seminar was 1 per cent only, I would be holding up my hands and saying: 'Thank God for the 1 per cent; we have got something'. I believe that, as a result of this seminar, we will get the co-operation of the media in getting across the message that we must get across in the interests of humanity.

talk.start.para: - On 7th December last Senator Davidson asked me a question without notice as follows:

quote.para: I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Education and Science. I ask whether the Minister has noted the reported results of an independent survey conducted at the University of Sydney in which it was reported that most Arts graduates do not take the course for a career? Has lie noted also that 41 per cent of the people concerned have received no advice on the selection of subjects and 43 per cent of those who have received advice have regarded it as of no help? Because of the public funds involved and the importance of Australia's education programme at the tertiary level, will the Minister make enquiries as to the effectiveness of advisory services regarding careers and will he obtain information on Arts courses at Australian universities with a view to assisting with the channelling of student ability into successful vocations?

speech.para: As I explained at the time, I believe that the study of the Arts has a very wide and fundamental importance for our general student population and I therefore said that I thought it was a subject on which 1 should give the Minister an opportunity to make a considered statement. The Minister for Education and Science has now provided me with the following comments:

quote.para: Traditionally universities have provided many courses wilh a view to general education as well as lo the provision of vocational training. This is well known lo students and many choose to pursue an Arts course and sometimes a Science course for the benefit of their general education or because, on entering university, they have no firm idea of the occupation they wish to follow in life.

I note that Senator Davidson's concern is related mainly to the provision of advice to students about the nature of Arts courses, (he subjects they might study and the career prospects at the end of such a course. All universities provide advisory services to students and these are constantly being improved and developed. However, many students do not seek advice, and many do nol fully appreciate advice when given. Moreover, the reason for the difficulty of those who sought advice but later claimed (hat it was of no assistance may well lie in the fact that they entered university without any real understanding of the career they wished to follow and enrolled for an Arts course in the belief that the acquisition of a degree would automatically qualify them for a career. But, as I have explained, training for a specific career is not the basic aim of many university courses although it is my feeling that universities do have some obligation, when designing courses, lo have some regard to the employment possibilities of graduates. I also believe thai secondary schools have an increasingly important role *o play in career guidance and counselling.

However, I should say that, while Arts courses are often no* directed to particular vocations, nevertheless they provide a broad basis for education which, wilh experience on the job or postgraduate training at university or college ot advanced education, does in fact suit people for a wide variety of occupations. Moreover there is a number of disciplines taught within faculties of Arts which lead directly to professional work, for example, Economics and Psychology. I have also noted, that a considerable proportion of students enrolled at the Canberra College of Advanced Education are first degree graduates from the Australian National University who. after their general degree course, are entrolling for graduate courses in Librarianship, Teaching and Secretarial Studies.

A number of overseas countries is also experiencing growing difficulties on the question of availability of suitable employment for certain types of graduates. Historically, graduates have been sought after for employment but with the increasing number of graduates, the certainty of their gaining employment of their first choice is diminishing. However, Senator Davidson will appreciate thai government, industry and commerce cannot be expected to create jobs to accommodate particular training or specialisations. Training in specialist areas does not create a right to a particular job. On the other hand, as I have said earlier,I do not believe that we can leave the question of job opportunity for the student alone to resolve. The student will need guidance and help and this is not possible without the close and continuing liaison between employing authorities and universities.

As I am personally concerned about the employment prospects of certain types of university graduates I have asked the Chairman of the Australian Universities Commission to consult with the Department of Labour and National Service at the earliest opportunity with a view to ascertaining the extent of the problem and indicating, if necessary, possible remedies.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice:

item.label: (I)
item.para: Is the Minister aware of a practice by the National Employers Mutual General Insurance Association whereby they seek to coerce members of the Rubber Workers' Union, who are contributorsto the Hospitals Contribution Fund of Australia, to claim for the cost of treatment for injuries sustained through industrial accidents from the Hospitals Contribution Fund rather than from the Association.

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

item.para: I am not aware of any practices of the nature referred to and the rules of registered hospital benefits organisations are diesigned to protect contributors from such practices. For example, the rules of the Hospitals Contribution Fund preclude the payment of fund benefits to persons who are entitled to full coverage under Third Party insurance or Workers' Compensation. Also, the National Health Act precludes the payment of Commonwealth benefits in such cases. However, where the amount of compensation is insufficient to cover the medical or hospital expenses, Commonwealth and fund benefits may be payable in certain circumstances.

Any person who deliberately sets out to obtain benefits fraudulently would have to falsify documents. The medical claim form used by registered organisations includes a direct question - which must be answered by the contributor either yes' or 'no' - as to whether he has an entitlement under workers' compensation or third parly insurance in respect of the particular illness or disability for which benefits are claimed. The claim form must be signed by the contributor who thereby declares that the information is true and correct.

speech.para: Similar conditions apply to claims for hospital benefits in thatthe certificate of hospitalisation (Form H.B. 21) issued by hospitals requires the contributor to certify that the hospitalisation does not involve workers' compensation or third party. It is a usual prerequisite to the payment of hospital benefits that a Form H.B. 21 be produced. If the patient is entitled to workers' compensation, the hospital should not issue a Form H.B. 21.

In so far as Commonwealth benefits are concerned, the National Health Act by virtue of sec- tions 30 and 62 provides for a penalty of $200 or imprisonment for six months for any false or misleading statement that involves the payment of Commonwealth benefits which otherwise would not he payable.

Apart from the safeguards provided by these forms, both the Hospitals Contribution Fund and officers of my Department maintain a scrutiny of claims, and persons suspected to have falsified accounts, claims or receipts may be prosecuted.

I would regard the type of practice described as a serious matter.I suggest that the honourable senator make any information regarding specific cases available to me so that I can have them fully investigated.

talk.start.para: - 1 move:

quote.para: That the Film Classification Ordinance 1971, as contained in Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 25 of 1971, and made under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910-1970, be disallowed.

speech.para: The object of moving the motion to disallow the Ordinance is not related to the whole content of the Ordinance nor to the substance of it but merely to sections 4 and 5, and to sections 6 and 7 which deal wilh the penalty prescribed for a breach of sections 4 and 5. Section 4 states: (1.) The exhibition of a film to persons on payment of a charge or on presentation of a ticket or other token is prohibited unless -

item.label: (a)
item.para: the film has been registered under the State Act and it is exhibited under the name under which it is so registered and in the form, without alteration or addition, in which it is so registered; or

item.label: (b)
item.para: the film is a Mim that has been exempted from registration under the State Act.

speech.para: Section 5 states: (1.) This section applies to a film that has been registered under the State Act after the prescribed date.

The prescribed date is defined in section 3 as follows: the prescribed date' means the date of commencement of the Theatres and Public Halls and Cinematograph Films (Amendment) Act, 1971 of the State of New South Wales.

Section 5 continues: (2.) The exhibition of a Rim to which this section applies to persons on payment of a charge or on presentation of a ticket or other token is prohibited unless, at the commencement of the exhibition of the film, there is exhibited an image that specifies -

item.label: (a)
item.para: the classification that has been assigned to the film under the State Act; or

item.label: (b)
item.para: the symbol that is the appropriate symbol for the classification assigned to the film under the State Act. (3.) The publication, by any, means whatsoever, of advertising matter relating to a film to which this section applies is prohibited unless the adver tising matter contains in a position in which it is clearly visible having regard to the size and nature of the advertising matter -

item.label: (a)
item.para: a statement specifying the classification assigned to the film under the Stale Act; or

item.label: (b)
item.para: the symbol that is the appropriate symbol for the classification assigned to the film under the State Act.

speech.para: The penalty section is section 6. lt states:

quote.para: Where a film is exhibited in contravention of section 4 or 5 of this Ordinance, the person who conducts the exhibition of the film and the person who has the management and control of the place at which the film is exhibited are each guilty of an offence against this Ordinance and are liable, on conviction, to a penalty not exceeding One hundred dollars.

speech.para: Section 7 states:

quote.para: Where advertising matter in relation lo a film is published in contravention of sub-section (3.) of section 5 of this Ordinance, the person who caused the advertising matter to be published is guilty of an offence against this Ordinance and is liable, on conviction, to a penalty not exceeding One hundred dollars.

speech.para: The question is whether the penalty imposed, which is a maximum penalty not exceeding $100, is appropriate to effect the purpose for which it is designed. The Ordinance deals with the recognition of the classification of films and films to be designated for restricted audiences and if the penalty is not appropriate in the inhibitive sense it is only an invitation to those who are prepared to exploit certain types of presentations to take advantage of that and, at the cost of the. minds of the young, to be prepared to risk a minor penalty which they would more than recoup by the additional patronage they would get from those who came to see a certain type of film which was not designated as a film unsuitable for children. Parents could come accompanied by children, in the absence of the specification of the type of film, and what might be gained in admission fees might more than counter-balance any penalty that might be imposed. The penalty is only a maximum of $100; it could be very much less. From reading the Press we do know of the very sophisticated types of films which unfortunately are available and that many films which could not fall into that category are actually quite unsuitable for any presentation and certainly for presentation to restricted audiences.
The Ordinance appears to incorporate the classification of films according to the

State definition. In this case the appropriate State would be New South Wales which is contiguous to the Australian Capital Territory. 1 asked officers of the Department of the Interior about this matter and the advice, I received was that the actual method of classifying films throughout the Commonwealth was introduced on a uniform basis and in general terms penalties have been fixed on a similar basis. Apparently there is no uniformity in relation to penalties. If my recollection is correct, the maximum penalty for a breach of this kind under New South Wales law is $200. In the contiguous area - the A.C.T. - maximum penalty is $100. I think that would be a quite unsuitable differentiation and it might render almost nugatory the penalty which is imposed in Canberra. 1 do not want to debate the subject at length. That was the basis of my moving the disallowance of the Ordinance. I shall be interested to hear the comment of the Minister for Civil Aviation (Senator Cotton) on the matter. If the Minister is able to indicate that there is good and sufficient reason for the penalty which has been fixed in the Australian Capital Territory and that it is appropriate for the offence, against the general background of the violation of this type of law, I will not attempt, to make it impossible for the Ordinance to go into complete and permanent operation. I had in mind to hear what the Minister said. If, in my best judgment an adequate case is made out I will be prepared to withdraw my motton. I do ask the Minister, if in retrospect the Department finds that, the penalty is inadequate or that it is undesirable that the penalty in the Australian Capital Territory is different from that in the contiguous State of New South Wales, to give an undertaking to review the Ordinance to see whether perhaps on re-examination a higher or a parallel penalty might not be imposed. 1 shall be delighted to hear the Minister's response to my remarks.

talker.electorate: New South WalesMinister for Civil Aviation
talker.name: COTTON, Bob
Senator COTTON

talk.start.para: - I think I might begin by reversing the normal process of argument. Senator Byrne may rest assured that if it is ascertained that in the light of experience a larger penalty is warranted or that if a larger penalty would improve the situation, make it better and set a stronger discipline a review of the

speech.para: Ordinance would be sought. The background of the matter, as J understand it, is something like this: The sub-section of the Ordinance requires advertising matter to have clearly visible on it a statement specifying the classification assigned to the film or the appropriate symbol of that classification and the penalty for an offence under that sub-section is one not exceeding $100. As a result, offences and penalties provided in the State Acts and in the Australian Capital Territory Ordinance are generally - I underline that word because I took note of what Senator Byrne had to say - on a par with each other, with minor differences resulting from individual requirements of each State.

For example, the penalties provided in the Australian Capital Territory and the various States for publishing an advertisement for a film which does not contain a statement specifying the film's classification or appropriate symbol are: Australian Capital Territory $100; New South Wales $100 - that is the figure I have been given; South Australia $50; Tasmania $50: and Victoria $100. I have a great number of other notes which 1 do not think would really help Senator Byrne or the argument. As Minister representing the Minister for the Interior, I take the point Senator Byrne has made. talk.start.para: - What is the penalty in New South Wales?

- I have been given a figure of $100. At this point of time and in the situation in which I am placed, I cannot go further than that. I hope that will be sufficient for the honourable senator.

- in reply - 1 am indebted to Senator Cotton. I intimated to him earlier what my attitude might be. 1 can see the problem. I would hope that, in the light of any experience that might be gained in the operation of this Ordinance, if it were found that the penalty as prescribed was not a sufficient deterrent the Department of the Interior would be alert to make sure that a more adequate, more severe and deterrent penalty was provided.

speech.para: I was under the impression that the New South Wales penalty was $200. If that is so, I think there is a strong case for uniformity in penalty. But the Minister agrees that there has been no uniformity in penalty. 1 should like the Minister to give thought to this: If there has been uniformity in classification, it is very difficult to sec why there should not be uniformity in penalty, lt seems to be extraordinary that, although the malice is uniformly accepted, the punishment that it attracts is not uni formly accepted.
