subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 2 March (vide page 391), on motion by Senator Drake-Brockman:

quote.para: That the Bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: - This Bill was brought into the Senate last week. It deals with a section of the Income Tax Assessment Act and is designed to restore in legislative form the additional depreciation allowance granted to manufacturing industries. This allowance was first introduced in 1962. It was withdrawn in the last Budget when the Government laid down a strategy to deal with the stagflation which was threatening the economy then and which has now worsened. The Government is taking one step back from that strategy which has been criticised by the Australian Labor Party and many other people in the community. But we members of the Opposition have very grave doubts that this is the level at which the Government ought to be taking a step.

speech.para: When this allowance was introduced in 1962 it was opposed by the Opposition. Because of the very full debate that took place in both chambers on that occasion and in the House of Representatives on this occasion, I do not intend to go into the matter as fully as I might if it was a proposition being introduced for the first time. But I intend to say one or two things about it. Senator Drake-Brockman, in introducing the Bill, said:

quote.para: This step has been taken on the basis of views put to us strongly from many quarters that restoration of the allowance is likely to be conducive to greater confidence and activity.

speech.para: He did not say what those quarters were; but, very obviously, the manufacturing industries would have been putting pressure on the Government.I have no doubt that pressure is applied to the Government in the field of taxation by all sorts of vested interests in the community. I move the following amendment:

quote.para: Leave out all words after 'That', insert 'the Bill be withdrawn because it is unselective in its approach and, gives no consideration to balanced economic development'.

speech.para: We might be asked why we do not oppose theBill outright. What we want to do is to indicate to the Government that steps ought to be taken to do something about the economic situation in which Australia finds itself today, and to indicate to the Government that this is not the best step to take. In fact, in many ways this is a very unwise step to take.

This allowance was introduced on 7th February 1962, following the 1961 election which was very closely fought. The allowance is now being reintroduced, strangely enough, in February again, just 10 years later, when we are on the eve of an election which promises to have at least some hazards for the Government. The Government has adopted the unusual approach of using the Income Tax Assessment Act to give what is, in effect, a subsidy to a section of industry. The poor old Income Tax Assessment Act is pretty elastic. It is stretched in all sorts of ways. To that extent,I suppose, this approach is not so novel. But, as was commented in 1962 - the more I look at this proposition, the more I believe it - this proposition stretches the elastic just a little too far.

The plant and equipment to which this allowance applies is subject to ordinary or historic depreciation. If somebody buys an article of plant and equipment for the purposes of his business he can write it off over varying lengths of time. Whether there is any importance in the length of time over which the article can be written off, I suppose, is bound up with the exercise of caution by the Taxation Office. It appears to me that the end results are just about the same whether the article is written off over X number of years or Y number of years. But this allowance is something in addition to the ordinary or historic depreciation. It is given in the first year of installation of machinery as a special type of depreciation which is nothing more nor less than a subsidy. Subsidies are not strange to the Australian setup. They are embodied in all sorts of things. The thing which seems to be strange, as we have mentioned, is that they are unselective. They are unselective because if an industry is not doing so well - slipping backwards - it is obvious that this allowance is not going to be much help to that industry. It appears to me that that is the industry which ought to be assisted.I suppose it can be marked, depending on the size of the industry and providing that it is a manufacturing industry. But it does seem that this allowance will be a very great help to the industry that does not need assistance as much as the one which is slipping backwards.

As I. understand the situation, there is a tremendous amount of under-capacity in the community today. It seems to me that if those people who have an under-capacity say: 'All right, we will take advantage of this', we are just exacerbating the position and putting in machinery which is not going to produce. It is not going to employ people and put goods into the Australian economy which, on a prima facie approach, is what this Bill is intended to do. This Bill is indiscriminating because it treats all manufacturing industries the same. One would think that with all the different facets about which the Government has been talking recently it might have aimed at strengthening those things which it professes to be worried about. Only in the last couple of days I noticed that there was talk that we must do something more about foreign investment in Australia; that we must get some idea of where foreign investment is lying; to what degree it is getting a stranglehold on Australia's industries; and whether the prime purpose of bringing both know-how and capital into Australia is to give us those things which we lack and to develop those industries which need assistance. We need to get some idea whether that is happening or whether money from overseas is merely going into those industries in which we can do so well ourselves and merely transfer the profit from Australians to foreigners.

One wonders whether this concession would not have been aimed at those manufacturing industries in Australia which are doing something in the export business. It seems strange that the Government is now assisting breweries which seem to me to be expanding at an ever greater rate. The stock exchange people are always advocating that one invest in breweries. There does not seem to be any great need to assist them. I mention breweries as one example of this tendency. Should not this concession have been aimed at the electronics industry or the motor car industry which, obviously, has an over-capacity at the moment? It is a great employer of labour but at the moment it is putting men off and it intends to put more off in the future.

Recently, reading an article. I was impressed with the problem of skilled tradesmen. Australia is a small country. If we look at the other smaller countries we find that they have been able to take their place to a very marked degree because of the skills they have been able to engender in order to make up for the lack of numbers. The Swiss are well known for their precision watchmaking. Sweden is able to produce aircraft and is able to lead in the boatbuilding business even though it is a small nation. One always tends to think of Japan which is, of course, the biggest boatbuilding nation. Of course, Japan is a big nation. But the smaller nations are able to compete, make a profit, employ people and do something in their own industries. Spain is another small country where, at the moment, I understand the Government has a Minister looking at boatbuilding.

A problem which has been marked and emphasised in documents is that industry is worried about where we are going in relation to skilled tradesmen. As men are put off in industry it is not the skilled tradesmen who are first to go. Obviously, industries do not want to lose their skilled tradesmen because, like Micawber, they arc going to wait for something to turn up. Such industries do not want to be scavenging around the country trying to get back their skilled tradesmen. If honourable senators have a look at the figures they will see how markedly the number of apprentices has dropped off. It is very obvious that in the future there will be fewer skilled workers coming on to the market than industry will employ. One wonders whether a survey ought not to be made and, if these doubts have some validity, should we not be assisting industry for the long terra in relation to skilled tradesmen? This means, of course, that an amount of money would have to be made available.

I do not think this was mentioned in the Minister's second reading speech but I understand that it is anticipated that this scheme will cost the Government about S5{)m. We should consider whether this money should be spent helping industry in this or other ways. As T say. it might be best spent in assisting export industry or those industries which are going to buy machinery which is manufactured in Australia. It may be best spent on those industries producing goods which have a high Australian content, lt may be that consideration should be given to other industries which have so many other facets to them. It seems to us that this Bill is indiscriminating. It does not distinguish between those industries which badly need help on a short term basis and those which do not. What effect will this allowance have on public investment if it goes to places which are already thriving and attracting a great deal of public investment? Will it not mean that more investment will go into that area where, obviously, it is not needed at all.

Also, it is obvious that the Government has confined this concession to the manufacturing industries. There is no argument in the Minister's second reading speech to show that this is the section of industry which requires help in order to have the quickest effect on the stagflation through which we are going today. The Prime Minister (Mr McMahon) made some trenchant remarks recently in relation to Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd. He now turns around and gives the manufacturing section of its manufacturing business some sort of boost under the Bill which is before us today.

As I say, in 1962 this matter was fully canvassed. Of course that is the time when it should have been. I think that that was the first time that taxation provisions were stretched so far as to make a direct subsidy to manufacturing industries. The matter was debated in this place and amendments were moved to clause 7 of the Bill - as it was in those days - which were quite unsuccessful. Because I would be repeating a lot of material which is already in Hansard I shall not go into this matter as fully as 1 would otherwise. 1 have moved this amendment as an indication to the Government that we feel it has struck in the wrong place. A lot more should be done. We claim that this is a retreat. The Government is acknowledging that its Budget strategy was wrong. But we believe that this is not the right area in which to rectify it. We state our reasons in the amendment and put on record why we believe this Bill should be withdrawn. 1 commend the amendment to the Senate.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Lawrie) - Is the amendment seconded?

talk.start.para: - 1 second the amendment.

- 1 welcome this Income Tax Assessment Bill and commend the Government for reinstating the investment allowance of 20 per cent on manufacturing plant and equipment. At the time of the suspension of this investment allowance I expressed my concern at that decision and said that 1 hoped that before very long the allowance would be restored to industry. I regard the investment allowance on new plant and equipment as being vital to the maintenance of productivity and efficiency in industry. If we want to hold down prices on the base things which we produce in Australia and the base things we want to export to markets then we have to produce them as cheaply as possible. I notice that in Great Britain 80 per cent is the investment concession for new plant and equipment. In some instances, the total value of the plant can be written off in the year in which it is installed. When we see the need locally, in big enterprises and in small, to match world competition this sort of action by government is the sort of action which is an incentive to the individual and to industry organisationally but in the process is of real value io the whole economy. I always have a very great concern for the retention of business activity in the hands of the small man as much as is possible in a world which is very difficult for him against the mass producers. If there is one thing that helps small industrial ventures in Australia it is this allowance. At a time when capital requirement bears heavily on those indus tries which in order to exist or to continue their activities must be competitive, this 20 per cent allowance in the year of installation is of real assistance to the capital standing of small enterprises.

speech.para: I speak with some knowedge of this matter as it applies in practice. If we look around any sector of industry in Australia we note that where those interests which have not taken advantage of this sort of incentive have allowed their plant to run down, inevitably they have finished up in a position where they are unable to carry on their activities. It is only those organisations and persons who keep their plant modern that have an opportunity and an ability to carry on and to make their unit really viable, both in volume production and in cost per unit of that production. I have a very definite idea on the law of diminishing returns. I do not accept that gigantic size alone is the only criterion for success in industry. Efficiency can be equally important, and perhaps more important. If general efficiency through maximum use of a given part of the plant is insisted upon in every respect, the small enterprise can be of very great assistance to the economy overall and in the process retain a rugged individualism which I think is of vital necessity to any nation. We need people who are prepared to risk their own capital in their own way; to be masters of their own ship and not just someone operating in an impersonal setting. These rugged individualists should be encouraged for they can be the salt of a nation in the economic field.

We have heard some criticisms of this Bill. 1 regret that the Opposition has seen fit to suggest that the Bill be withdrawn because it is unselective in its approach, as the Opposition states in its amendment, and gives no consideration to balanced economic development. The amendment states that the Bill is unselective. All industry, small and big, in my opinion, has to be given this sort of background ability to be efficient. I have no doubt, as I said when 1 began to speak, that productivity is the great need in our economy today. We have to keep costs down in industry. I cannot see anything more beneficial to that end than the purchase of new plant, from lnc point of view of power consumption, la bour required, and the ability to turn out more articles or uni;s in a given time. This is the basis of economic production. This is the basis for keeping prices down on our horns market. This is the basis for enabling us lo compete on overseas markets. If we do not give to industry here in Australia allowances such as this investment allowance we have before us today and which arc comparable to those allowances which are given in all other countries, how on earth can we expect to compete? I have much pleasure indeed in supporting this Bill.

talk.start.para: - The Australian Democratic Labor Party supports the Bill and finds itself unable to accept the amendment moved by the Opposition. This Bill embodies the type of fiscal discipline which it is within the power of a government to impose when it is necessary to control the economy either by restriction or by expansion, and the Government has been faced with this very extraordinary situation in more recent times when we have experienced a rise in prices, a rise in costs, and also a rise in the level of unemployment. In its wisdom the Government has decided that there must be a stimulation of the economy. This is one of the fiscal means which has been adopted by the Government in order to bring this about, lt could have adopted a method by which taxation would have been reduced, and that would have had the same effect - perhaps not as rapidly or perhaps more rapidly. However, this allowance is the method that has been selected. I think we all agree that some stimulation in the economy was necessary.

speech.para: The Opposition has suggested that the Bill should be withdrawn because the benefit granted is not selective. I should imagine that to try to extend this benefit on a selective basis might be administratively very difficult, and in the new concept of the diversified undertaking it may bc extraordinarily hard to classify operations as falling within a category which would attract the benefit or, on the other hand, may not be able to attract it. In these circumstances it would make for an extraordinarily difficult administrative situation. I do think that in the balance of advantage and across the board benefit of this kind, the uniform investment allowance for the installation of plant and equipment is possibly the best and administratively the most efficient way in which this can be done.

However, 2 effects flow from this. One, of course, is that it should result in the production of more capital goods. That in itself in a time when we need reemployment in some of our manufacturing industries where labour displacement is occurring is important because it will immediately attract labour to the production of that equipment and that plant which manufacturers will be seeking in view of the investment allowance now being given. But perhaps more importantly it will result in the introduction to industry of more efficiency by the provision of more modern plant and equipment. After all, a.s Senator Laucke so correctly and wifely said, ultimately economies in the modern competitive world must rest on their achievement or failure to reach a high standard of competitive efficiency. We know that it is now a matter of history that the great commercial advance in West Germany after the war was due to the fact that all her industries were virtually destroyed, or the allies, as part »f reparation arrangements, took a lot of her machinery away and installed it in their own fabricating enterprises. Germany, therefore, had to re-equip from the ground up. She necessarily re-equipped with the most modern machinery and equipment, and that gave her the great opportunity for the dynamic industrial leap forward which has raised her now to a position of industrial eminence over the whole world.

We would hope that there would be a response from manufacturing industries to this investment allowance, lt is now up to the enterprises concerned to take advantage of it, to see that their plants are brought up to the highest possible level of efficiency so that they will not only benefit the commercial operations of their own companies but will benefit also the economy and do a considerable amount to help the unemployment situation.

For those reasons we of the Democratic Labor Party do not see any reason to have the Bill withdrawn. It will be interesting to sec whether a remedy such as this will have the expected effect on the economy, either at the level hoped for or at a greater level. The Government found- itself under pressure to do something about the condition of the economy. That it responded in this way is commendable. We hope that the diversion that Senator Willesee looks for will be realised. We hope that the investment allowance will be spent, in the main, in those industries which will produce the type of goods we want, the type which are necessary both in the economic sense and for the technological operations of the nation. I have little doubt that that will be the case. Therefore I think we should welcome this Bill. We trust that there will be an enthusiastic response from industry, both in the industries fabricating goods that will attract such an investment allowance and in the enterprises that will install the necessary plant. We hope that the beneficial results we seek will stem from this legislation. We support the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator DrakeBrockman) adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 2 March (vide page 419), on motion by Senator Cotton:

quote.para: Thai the Bill be now read a second lime.

talk.start.para: - The Senate has before it 3 Bills, the Broadcasting and Television Bill 1972, the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Bill 1972 and the Television Stations Licence Fees Bill 1972. Subject to the approval of the Minister for Air (Senator Drake-Brockman), because they were taken together in the House of Representatives and because the 2 last named Bills relate to (he first Bill, I suggest that (he 3 Bills be debated at the one lime.
- I am agreeable to that course being followed.

speech.para: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Lawrie) - There being no objection, that course will be followed.

The principal objects of the first Bill, namely, the Broadcasting and Television Bill 1972, are three-fold. Firstly, it seeks to amend sections 84 and 105c of the Act to provide that a licence may be renewed for a period of not less than 6 months or not more than 3 years rather than the mandatory one-year renewal period that exists now under the Act. This amendment is being sought specifically so that in the first renewal period the length of renewal can be varied in order that the future renewal dates for a number of licences held by one company or one group of companies can be synchronised. This means that after the initial renewal period all licences held by the one company or the one group of companies will be considered in the form of a total operation, thus permitting a single report to be furnished to the PostmasterGeneral (Sir Alan Hulme) on the operations and administration of all the licences held by that company or group of companies. This, according to the second reading speech of the Minister for Civil Aviation (Senator Cotton), will reduce the work load of the Australian Broadcasting Control Board and those making the applications for renewal.

Secondly, this Bill seeks to amend sections 90c and 92 of the Act in order, we of the Opposition suggest, to protect further the interests of persons and companies which have had special privileges, so far as ownership is concerned, conferred upon them by being allowed to retain more than the prescribed interest in the ownership and control of television and broadcasting station licences as a result of the December 1964 provision in the Act. In other words, the Bill is intended to extend the protection, as we see it, to the specially privileged licensed section wherever there has been a change in the circumstances under which the interests are held.

Thirdly, this Bill seeks to amend section 1 1 7(4.) to provide for the name of the speaker and author of a political announcement during an election period to be announced only after the political message has been given, rather than before and after as is the case at present. The Bill also seeks to amend the section to provide that any person making written application to the Austraiian Broadcasting Commission or to a commercial licensee for the name and address of the author and speaker snail receive such details.

In the House of Representatives the Labor Party moved that the Bill be referred to a joint select committee to inquire into and report upon the conditions under which television and broadcasting licences are granted and renewed. That amendment was defeated. Therefore, for reasons which I will enumerate shortly, on behalf of the Opposition in the Senate 1 now move:

quote.para: Leave out all words after 'That', insert 'the Bill be withdrawn until the Senate Standing Committee on Education, Science and the Arts presents its Report on the matter referred to it by the Senate on 19th August 1971, viz.: All aspects of television and broadcasting, including Australian content of television programmes'.

speech.para: I understand that, that amendment now U being circulated.

I have moved thai amendment to the motion for the second reading principally for 2 reasons. Firstly, we of the Opposition say that a standing committee of the Senale at this very time is engaged in inquiring into idi aspects of mass media, including ownership and control. For the Government to present legislation of this nature to the Senate when a standing committee of the Senate has been directed by the Senate to embark upon such an inquiry, and indeed is in the course of embarking on that inquiry, is an affront to that committee and to the Senate. Secondly, we say that to present such legislation shortly before a Federal election is lo be held - a general election certainly will be held this year - is intended to protect further the existing control of certain newspaper groups in the event of a Labor government being elected at (he next election.

True it is, as the Minister said in his second reading speech, provision exists, under section 86 of the Act, for the suspension and revocation of licences in specified circumstances. However, in plain terms, throughout the history of the Aci the Government has never acted, nor is it likely ever to act against any of its strongly entrenched commercial friends, notwithstanding the extent of any breach thai might be committed by a commercial licensee. In view of the fact that the Government may, if it considers it necessary, take action lo revoke a licence under seclion 86 of the Act, we regard as a lame duck excuse on the part of the Government its reason for bringing forward this legislation at this stage. We say that the

Government should have awaited the Senate Standing Committee's report on this important aspect of the mass media, including the question of ownership and control, before going ahead with legislation of this nature.

This legislation and the Minister's remarks in another place appear to be an open admission by the Government of its disregard for public interest because the very reasons advanced as to the purposes of the Bill suggest that the clauses, when enacted, will ease the work load on the Board and on the commercial licensees and will enable all applications for renewals of licences held by one company or group to be dealt with en masse. There seems to be inbuilt in this legislation a general understanding that, notwithstanding the seriousness of a breach or a number of breaches of the Act that may occur, all licences held by one company or a group of companies will be considered collectively by the Australian Broadcasting Control Board and then referred collectively to the Minister for his approval. The PostmasterGeneral, in the course of his remarks in another place, cited the example of one company which has control of the maximum number of broadcasting stations allowed by the Act. The Minister said at that time that although the Act required the company to amend its articles of association, it was an old established company and it did not want to alter its articles of association. Apparently, merely because the company was not prepared to alter its articles of association to conform with the Act, the Government has had to fall into line with the company's wish and has put the Australian people and the Parliament to the trouble and expense of amending the Act so that it will conform with the company's articles of association.

We of the Opposition believe that that is a ludicrous situation for any government to be in. Surely this indicates how these vested interests can stand over the Government. When amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act were being considered by the Senate in 1969 T said that because of the timid policies pursued by the Government towards commercial licensees, the Australian Broadcasting Control Board had become a mere service agency to the commercial interests and that the public was being regarded as no more than a collection of spectators who watch television for the want of something better to do. Consequently we have asked why the Government should not await the report of the Senate Standing Committee before moving in the- way that it has moved to amend this Act. We have asked whether licensees, particularly those who operated under special provisions prior to the provision being inserted in the Act in 1964. have said to the Government: 'Move now, before it is loo late.'

The concentration of ownership of Australian mass media is frightening. One has to refer only to appendix J to the last annua! report of the Broadcasting Control Board to see the extent of the ownership and control of the mass media and how it is vested in too few hands. One will see in that appendix 15 pages of small type setting out the multiple shareholding interests of newspaper proprietors and others in broadcasting and television stations in Australia.

talk.start.para: - That was one of the initial mistakes that we made.

speech.para: True - a great mistake was made when these licences were granted. I suggest that if a Labor government had been in office probably none of these newspaper companies would have been granted a licence. I invite honourable senators to compare the situation in Canada with that which prevails here. In December 1970 a special Senate committee on mass media in Canada submitted a 1,117 page report on its 2-year investigation of media trends. One of the major conclusions reached by the Committee was that any further concentration of ownership in the Canadian mass media would be undesirable and contrary to the public interest. The Canadian Senate committee recommended, among other things, a Press ownership review board to approve or disapprove of any future transactions that might tend towards a concentration of ownership or a monopoly. But in Australia, although the Senate has established a Standing Committee to inquire into this aspect upon which the Canadian Senate committee reported to the Canadian Parliament the Government has decided to act to protect even further the interests of the owners of the mass media. This has happened only months before a Federal election and at a time when the Senate Standing Committee is investigating the situation.

Last year in the spring edition of a publication called 'Journalism Quarterly' there appeared a report of a study carried out at the University of Minnesota in the United States in relation to the concentration of Press ownership and circulation of newspapers in 32 different countries. The study revealed that among the developed countries, after Ireland, Australia had the next tightest control of its daily circulation. When it is taken into account that in Australia those who control the newspapers appear to control also the commercial television networks and some broadcasting stations, the situation becomes alarming, lt is much worse than the situation revealed by the publication issued by the University of Minnesota. This is why we have written into the Labor Party Platform that whilst the dual system of national and commercial radio and television will continue under a Labor government, the tendency towards monopoly is especially dangerous and must be resisted by appropriate legislation. This is why we have said that under a Labor government a fairness principle will be included in the legislation regulating radio and television so that opposing viewpoints will be ensured a fair opportunity of expression.

talk.start.para: - We might need to take the licences from some of them.

speech.para: Certainly the licences will need to be looked at. One of the reasons why we have moved this amendment is so that the Senate Standing Committee can present its report to the Senate on the extent of mass ownership and control. This is why we have said also that, in the public interest, a Labor government will undertake a complete review of the conditions upon which licences are granted and renewed and that all applications for issue and renewal of licences W" be heard in public.

This legislation, it appears to us, is the direct antithesis of Labor policy. Because we anxiously await the report of the Senate Standing Committee, we have moved the amendment to which I have alluded already. We have the very powerful AAP syndicated news going out from this Parliament to practically every newspaper in Australia. Frankly, I do not think that the Australian Broadcasting Control Board is being as fair as it should be in providing information to this Parliament about shareholding interests. For instance, on 3 1st March last Senator Gair received an answer to a question he had asked on 24th Febrary 1971 concerning whether a Mr H. E. If the Act does provide for such a declaration - I cannot see where it does - why does the Board not know about it and why does the Board not tell the Senate about it? talk.start.para: - It appears to me that the Government in this legislation is bending over backwards to condone what surely must be regarded as dubious manoeuvres, to say the least, in shareholding transactions and the formation and the financing of nominee companies to enable the protected companies under the 1965 legislation to make further grabs on the control of the mass media. I wish the Government would enforce section 114 of the Act which provides for the employment of Australians as much as possible in the production and presentation of broadcasting and television programmes.
- Have you ever suggested how that section might be enforced to give it teeth? Is it not meant to be only a general direction?
- It is a general direction, but I would suggest that the Australian Broadcasting Control Board lay down standards which could give to section 1 1 4 the teeth which apparently it does not have now.

- Yes. Surely the Government can say to the Broadcasting Control Board: 'We want teeth in this Act'. If the standards imposed by the Control Board are not sufficient to carry out Government policy the Government should ensure that the Act is amended to give protection to Australian performers. Let us take professional variety. In Australia today there are great professional variety artists, but about the only time one sees them on television is when a telethon is being run by a commercial station to raise funds for a very worthwhile charitable organisation. The professional variety artists are asked to give - they do so willingly - their services for such a pursuit. If only the Government would give to these people the protection, the rights and the opportunitties that it is giving to the controllers of the mass media I suggest that our country would be far better off.

speech.para: The Broadcasting and Television Act, as it is administered by the Government, can best be described, as I see it, as the Act of double standards. It provides for double standards in relation to ownership and in relation to the protection afforded to commercial licensees when compared with the lack of protection for performers. It provides for the protection of licensees against the Australian public generally as far as the growth of monopoly of ownership is concerned. An incoming Labor government is pledged to re-write the Act to provide for fair and equitable treatment for everyone. That was laid down by the Party at Launceston last year. A Labor government will take legislative and administrative steps to increase Australian content and to preserve a reasonable balance between material of overseas and Australian origin.

speech.para: The Bill seeks to do 3 things. It seeks to alter the period for which commercial broadcasting and television station licences are renewed, to make certain changes to the way in which share interests are held and, finally, to make a very small amendment to the requirement that at election time the name and address of the speaker and the person authorising a speech should appear at the end of a 100- word message instead of both at the beginning and the end. I do not propose to devote any time to the third proposition because it simply has to be stated to explain itself.

The Bill seeks to increase (he period of a licence up to 3 years. It should be observed that the Bill proposes to make the period a minimum of 6 months to a maximum of 3 years. That would give the Australian Broadcasting Control Board power to have an inquiry into a renewal much earlier should it deem that desirable. My friend Senator Douglas McClelland said that the Labor Party would conduct all inquiries into the renewal of licences in public. I rather gathered that the implication was that if the hearing for renewal were conducted in public fresh applications would be called for the renewal of licences. So, no licensee could hold his licence with certainty for more than 3 years. This would be inimical to development. A tremendous amount of capital and organisation goes into running, operating, owning and controlling a modern television station - more so a television station than a radio station.

I do not hedge on the point that in the past I have been as critical as Senator Douglas McClelland or anyone else has been of the way in which television licences were issued. I do not want to go back over that thorny past, which is many years behind us. We now have to live with the facts as they are. One of the big difficulties to which Senator Douglas McClelland did not advert is the very limited constitutional power which the Broadcasting Control Board has to deal with breaches of its standards. The Act provides - 1 am satisfied on the authorities thai it is a valid provision - that the Board can lay down standards which should be observed in the conduct of a television station. But from that point on the Board simply has power to write a letter drawing attention to a breach of its standards or, at the other extreme, after conducting a public inquiry it can cancel a licence. No-one in his right mind would cancel a licence for a breach of advertising standards, a breach of advertising time provisions or even a collection of such breaches. There is millions of dollars of capital involved; there is the money of thousands of shareholders involved. Accordingly, the power which the Broadcasting Control Board has to cancel a licence is so great and its operation has so many ramifications that it is one that must be exercised with the utmost discretion. I am speaking from memory now; I have not the records in front of me. I do not recall one instance in which a licence for a television station has actually been cancelled. I think one licence has been withdrawn or reallocated as a result of negotiation.

The problem which faces the Broadcasting Control Board, I believe, interests honourable senators opposite as much as it interests us on this side of the chamber. 1 refer lo a legal difficulty which is posed by the decision of the High Court of Australia in the boilermakers case in 1953. That decision, very briefly, laid down that judicial and administrative power cannot be granted by the Commonwealth Parliament to a single tribunal or a single authority. In other words, under the Constitution we have to keep the administrative power and the judicial power separate. That is correct, is it not, Mr Attorney?

talk.start.para: - Impeccably stated.

- That being the case, the Broadcasting Control Board does not have the power, even if the Government wanted to give it, to fine people, say, $50, $100 or $500 for breaches of the standards, because that would make the Board both the administrator and the judge of its own case.

speech.para: In the United States of America the Federal Communications Commission, which among many other . things does the job that the. Broadcasting Control Board does in Australia, is not hindered by the same constitutional problem. That Commission can impose a penalty and if the licensee feels aggrieved he can, of course, appeal to the courts. But the Federal Communications Commission in the United States is given a flexible day to day control over a licensee, which does not exist in this country. If honourable senators opposite could get together with the legal brains in the Government and devise some scheme whereby the Broadcasting Control Board could be given reasonable disciplinary power, I believe that there would be satisfaction all round.

In saying what I have said, I reserve my objections to the amendments to be moved by Senator Douglas McClelland, with the saving grace that I want to listen to the debate in regard to his second amendment which relates to defamation and to which he made no reference.

speech.para: The case of Elwood Pty Ltd to which Senator Douglas McClelland referred - I make no bones about it - seems to me to be worthy of investigation. I understand that it has been referred to previously; but now that he has given chapter and verse and referred to it in detail I presume it will be considered again by the relevant authorities. There is an aspect of the ownership and control of television and broadcasting stations in this country which t!he current legislation affects. On 17th December 1964 interests held by companies and organisations were not exactly frozen but they were fixed to the degree that companies were not able to own or control more than 2 television stations in capital cities. One of the protective provisions was that those who had already acquired those interests were to be allowed to retain them, provided the acquisition had been completed by the date in question and provided always that there was no alteration in the manner in which the shares were held. This legislation simply provides that the manner in which the shares are held may be altered provided always that the quantum or amount of the shareholding is not increased. To me that seems to be in line with the somewhat belated decision - if .1 may say so - to try to ensure the maximum distribution in the control, ownership and operation of the mass media.

Senator DouglasMcClelland referred to section J 14 of the Broadcasting and Television Act which requires the services of Australians to be used wherever practicable. I think I can say with all the modesty 1 can summons that I have been as vocal on this point as others, both inside and outside this chamber. A significant aspect of this matter which 1 think has not been canvassed in the chamber is that as from June of this year 50 per cent of the local content will have lo be shown in peak viewing times. That is between 6 o'clock and 10 o'clock in the evening. This is a tremendous step forward. It means that at the peak viewing times when programme matter is most competitive at least half the material will have to be of Australian origin. I think it will be conceded that this is a substantial step forward.

In addition the Board has provided that there must be - I think it is for 2 hours in every 28 days - a special children's programme put on at the times provided for this type of material. By and large I have every hope that as the requirements of the Board take effect, with the encouragement of the Government in other fields such as the Australian Film Development Corporation, the fledgling Australian industry will get off its feet and provide a proper quota of good quality material for television. I shall digress for a moment on Australian assessments. I regret to say that many of us are knockers of the local product. I do not know whether it is a form of inverted snobbery but many of us are prepared to criticise something simply because it is Australian. We were able to read in the Press 2 days ago about a film produced by Mr Neary's outfit called 'Wake in Fright'. This film ran very poorly in Melbourne and Sydney. It had no success at all. In the United States where it is now being shown it has been voted one of the 10 best films of the year.

talk.start.para: - And in France.

- -As Senator Douglas McClelland says, it has been successful in France. Knowing how perverse our own audiences are at times it would not surprise me that if the film were to be brought back here and shown now that it has succeeded abroad it would be a sellout. But perhaps that is being too cynical.
- it was entered in the Cannes festival.

- That is right. As Senator Douglas McClelland says it was entered in the Cannes festival. I believe it had some success there but I do not know what that success was. The Bill before the Senate is obviously designed to ameliorate the administrative position. It is one in which I do not think there is a great deal of ideological content. I support the measure before the chamber.
- The Australian Democratic Labor Party will vote for the amendment which has been moved by Senator Douglas McClelland and which states:

quote.para: Leave out all words after 'That', insert 'the Bill be withdrawn until the Senate Standing Committee on Education, Science and the Arts presents its report on the matter referred to it by the Senate on 19th August 1971, viz: AH aspects of television and broadcasting, including Australian content of television programmes'.

speech.para: In the unlikely event of that amendment being defeated we will vote for the other amendment in which Senator Douglas McClelland seeks the right of persons who feel agrieved by material which has been broadcast to be supplied with a copy of the material. I compliment Senator Douglas McClelland upon a speech which proved what we have already known and that is that this is a subject in which he takes a great deal of interest and in which he is certainly as well-informed as anybody in this chamber. I was interested to listen to Senator Hannan because we all know that he has had a considerable association in the television and radio field. But the reason why the Democratic Labor Party decided to support the amendment is that it appears to us that only in very important circumstances should the Government present a Bill to the Senate which deals with a matter which the Senate has already referred to a committee. I am a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Education, Science and the Arts. We have already had the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Control Board and other expert witnesses before us. We have in train preparations for a hearing upon a number of matters in which the matters contained in the Bill are included. We will be meeting on Thursday next to arrange the opening of our inquiry.

As I said before, to me it seems entirely wrong - unless a subject matter of the Bill concerned were extremely vital, urgent and important - that when we have organised and arranged for a committee to meet and examine a matter the Government should prejudge some of it and proposes to legislate on it. It appears to me that there is some similarity here to what I have noticed at times: In the last year or two when the Senate has appointed a committee to inquire into a certain subject there has been a sudden rush and we have found that an inter-departmental committee has been appointed at the same time, presumably with the idea of getting in first and trying to head off what the Senate Committee is trying to do.

talk.start.para: - That has happened on about 3 occasions.

- On at least 3 occasions the Senate has determined to have a Senate inquiry and somebody has rushed to the members of the Committee and said: 'An inter-departmental committee is going to take a look at this. Do you not think that you had better drop the whole thing?' Even Senator Hannan said that this Bill will help to streamline administration, but that, there is nothing in it of a revolutionary character. If there is nothing in the Bill of a revolutionary character, nothing that is very urgent, why the rush to put the Bill through? If we legislate now and the Committee reported that something needed to be altered there might have to be retrospective legislation. Listening to Mr Lynch over the past fortnight I have been terribly impressed about the dangers of retrospective legislation - so impressed that it has had an effect upon my thinking in regard to this matter.

speech.para: I do not propose to labour the points because, knowing the facts of life as we do, it would appear that the Bill will not get very far. As I am a member of the

Committee I will probably have a good deal to say there. In the circumstances there is not very much purpose in canvassing the field with which we are to deal. So I merely content myself by saying again that the Democratic Labor Party feels it is very wrong to bring before the Senate a Bill which it is openly admitted is not a terribly important Bill but which deals with subjects which will be discussed by a Committee of the Senate in the near future. It is entirely wrong to do so. We should protest against it. We will register our protest by voting for Senator Douglas McClelland's amendment.

talk.start.para: - I rise to refer to one matter which is of concern to me. Before doing so I would like to add to the remarks of Senator McManus concerning the contribution which has been made during the course of this debate and on previous occasions by Senator Douglas McClelland. I think we are all aware that he concentrates in this area and his concentration makes him a spokesman and an authority in this field. I think that not only does he do the Opposition a credit but also he does this Parliament a credit in the work that he does in the field of television stations and their ownership. The point I wish to raise is related to another committee which was formed last year for the purpose of looking at frequency modulation and the recent statement that we would see the introduction of colour television in this country in the next 3 years. It is true that there is no point in committees being appointed to inquire into these matters unless the reports of those committees are listened to by the Government and acted upon.

speech.para: In the case of the Senate Standing Committee on Education, Science and the Arts which was appointed to look into this matter, we find that whatever its findings may be they will be disregarded by the Government. Also the findings of the committee which is inquiring into frequency modulation broadcasting will be disregarded, because in an interview on the ABC's programme 'A.M.' on 17th February this year the Postmaster-General (Sir Alan Hulme) gave a clear indication that the findings of the committee on frequency modulation broadcasting would largely be disregarded. This is despite the fact that the committee took much evidence in public and it has been deliberating on its report for some months now. I understand its report will not be available for some time yet, which suggests that a good deal of work has been done by the committee in this field. Yet the Postmaster-General has told us that in fact the Government is not prepared to wait to find out what the committee's findings are.

This is a very serious matter, because in this country over the past few years since the introduction of television we have witnessed a decline in the standard of broadcasting. Television is a limited field. It has certain inbuilt deficiencies which colour will not overcome. Colour will certainly add colour to some aspects of television. Those who have seen colour television realise the visual impact that it has. But it is still a limited medium. Radio has been the neglected medium since the introduction of television. Tn particular the broadcasting of fine music has been neglected. If it were not for the Australian Broadcasting Commission and its concern to ensure that those members of the Australian public who are interested in fine music in fact do get some consideration there would be none broadcast at all.

I was interested to look through the report of the Australian Broadcasting Control Board for the year ended 30'h June 1971. We find on page 221 of the report an analysis of broadcasting programmes by the commercial stations. We find that entertainment, as it is called, which is a standard of entertainment I think well known to all of us, constitutes about 70 per cent of the fare given to the public by commercial broadcasting stations. The arts constitute 0.3 per cent of their programmes. That figure rises to 8.8 per cent when all broadcasting stations, including the Australian Broadcasting Commission, are taken into account. So we cannot expect to look to commercial radio or commercial television for good quality programmes in this country. I dare say that that is their business and 1 am not advocating that they should be told that they should broadcast concerts simply to satisfy 5 per cent or 10 per cent of the community. But it is a great shame that we should see the Federal Minister responsible for these matters pre-empting the findings of a committee appointed by this Government to inquire into the possibilities of frequency modulation broadcasting in this country.

The cost of pit ting FM broadcasting stations in each of the 5 capital cities might be in the vicinity of S2m, yet we think nothing of embarking on the introduction of colour television so thai we can see such nonsense as 'Division 4', Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck . in colour at a cost of something like $130m or SI 40m. I do not question that colour television must come, but it is a shame that it should be brought in with a complete disregard of those better qualities which radio can give us through frequency modulation broadcasting and which are being disregarded. I think it makes common sense that if we as a nation can afford colour televisions we can afford frequency modulation broadcasting. I will be watching, as I think many others will, to see what the findings of- this committee will be. If this Government is prepared simply to bypass its recommendations, if in fact they are in support of the introduction of frequency modulation broadcasting, it will be an indication of a complete lack of concern by this Government for that small segment of the community who are interested in better quality broadcasting in Australia. I hope that before any decision is made by this Government, whether or not it is announced, it will in fact listen to what this committee has to say and nol only give consideration to the desires of the mass of the community but also be concerned for those people who want something a little better than that sort of fare which is thrown at them by commercial television or commercial radio.

talk.start.para: - I have listened wilh interest to what has been said in this debate. Appreciating what the outcome of this debate will be, as Senator McManus invited me to do, I do not propose lo delay the Senate for very long. I. must say that I feel that much of what has been said insofar as it relates to the content of programmes on radio and .television is outside the ambit of this Bill. It may be that one takes a too strict view, of the ambit of the Bill in expressing a view of that character, but I feel that if one does examine what the provisions are it 'will be seen that they are designed to correct situations which experience has shown have existed and they do not move into the wider and more controversial area of programming.

speech.para: I appreciate that the Opposition and the Australian Democratic Labor Party have decided to oppose in effect the passage of this Bill. What they have indicated is that the Bill should be withdrawn until the Senate Standing Committee on Education, Science and the Arts has presented its report on the matter referred to it by the Senate on 19th August 1971. That matter was 'All aspects of television and broadcasting, including Australian content of television programmes'. In passing I make a comment which I think ought to be made: If the Government is required to take action, if it is to exercise its powers as a government, I think it should be able to proceed expeditiously from the introduction of legislation in the Parliament until its passage, providing always of course that the Parliament agrees with what the Government is doing. I do not believe" that the overall government of this country ought to be subordinated to the time which a lot of overworked senators can give to affairs in committees.

I know full well that the problems of the Standing Committee on Education, Science and the Arts have prevented a matter which was referred to it in August 1971 being taken up by that Committee until some time In 1972. But I do suggest to the Senate that as one House of the Parliament from which the Government is derived it has a responsibility to ensure that the legislation before it is properly considered and that the government of the country is not affected. I appreciate that the Broadcasting and Television Bill, notwithstanding what eloquence might be mustered on its behalf, could not be regarded as a vital Bill. I sense therefore that it ls thought to be an appropriate occasion for the Senate to flex its muscles and to indicate the power it has. I do not know whether the real power which the Senate possesses is best illustrated by action of this character on Bills which noone regards as of such importance or inherent merit that they must not be delayed pending the report of the Senate Committee.
As the second reading speech indicated, this Bill is concerned with 3 matters only.

The first is to provide for a 3-year renewal period whereas thus far there has been only a one-year renewal period. If any honourable senator examines the case put forward in support of that proposition in the second reading speech in this chamber and in the debates in the other place he cannot but be impressed with the fact that there is merit in getting rid of the one-year renewal period. There is the problem, of course, that certain stations may be in some form of technical breach at the time when their licence next comes up for renewal at the end of a year and it is advantageous for the licence to be renewed for a short period, say 6 months, on the condition that there will be a longer renewal if the omissions are repaired. Likewise there is merit in the proposition that if a number of interests are involved all the licences can be said to expire at the one time and there can be one report on all interests. If the report is satisfactory the period for renewal will be 3 years. I must say, despite all the arguments advanced as to why we should await the report of the Senate Standing Committee, that there has been no criticism directed to that particular provision. Yet it is the language of what is proposed. It seems to me to be a little incongruous that a Senate which values the work done by its committees is not prepared to examine legislation which comes before it on the merits of its provisions.

The second provision in the Bill is designed to adjust an anomaly which occurred in the freezing provisions with regard to the holding of interests in commercial television and radio stations. Those provisions were inserted with respect to commercial television stations in 1964 and with respect to commercial radio stations in 1969. They were very stringent provisions. I know that Senator Douglas McClelland developed the argument that these provisions are not as meaningful as he would like them to be but I feel that in his arguments he ignored, in the first place, the precise provisions in the legislation and, in the second place, the very real practical difficulties of imposing an alternative set of standards which can be enforced in a way which would be superior to the manner of enforcing the existing provisions. But these provisions do exist and they limit the number of prescribed interests which one company can have in licences of television or broadcasting stations. They not only limit the number of interests which can be held; they also define what represents an interest in a company and what represents control of a company.

As I said, these provisions, having been in existence for a number of years, have created a number of anomalies. Essentially the anomaly which it is designed to correct is the fact that there can be no movement whatsoever in the number of shareholdings or in the form of the shareholdings of companies which, prior to the commencement of these provisions, had interests in licences and which by virtue of the legislation are protected. Just to remind Senator McManus, the provision of 1964 was enacted so that there would be no retroactive effect on vested rights. That having occurred, it has been proved by experience that if a company engages, for example, in portfolio investment it may find that one of the shares in the company in which it has bought shares will have some small interest in a television station. It does not matter whether the increase in the original company's interest is .0001 per cent; that contravenes the provisions of the legislation. I think it is fair to say that this particular provision in the Bill was introduced to overcome that sort of anomaly. In short, a company cannot hold more shares than it held in 1964 at the time that these freezing provisions came into force. It does not matter if there is some change in the form of the holding which it held so long as the amount of shareholding is not increased. That, I think, is a reasonable provision and is amply justified by what has been said in support of it, but once again honourable senators have not said why it is not acceptable.

The third provision with which this legislation deals is the simple provision that a person should not when he is engaged in a political broadcast have to yield time, for which he is paying, at the beginning and at the end of a small political broadcast. At the present time he has to yield that time because the name and address of the author must be given at the beginning of the broadcast and likewise at the end of it. The provision contained in this Bill says that where the speech is in excess of 100 words the name and address of the author does not have to be given at the beginning and the end; it has to be given only at the end.

I must say - I say it, I hope, with a degree, of cynicism which the Senate will bear - that the matters involved in this particular measure are not the weighty measures which the Senate contemplated would be dealt with by the Senate Standing Committee on Education, Science and the Arts when there was referred to it 'All aspects of television and broadcasting, including Australian content of television programmes', lt is regrettable that the Senate is proposing to adopt a certain course, notwithstanding that the reasons why it is being adopted might be fairly readily apparent to the politically wary. I do not think it redounds to the credit of the Senate that this course is being taken.

In the course of the debate there was some reference by Senator Douglas McClelland lo particular transactions which had occurred and in respect of which he said there was demonstrated a widespread tendency to monopoly control in many interests which particular companies had in a number of television or radio stations. I have said to him that the language of the provisions of the Broadcasting and Television Act at the present time do lay down standards by providing for the percentage interest. They do indicate what is the controlling interest in a company and how many shares a person must have before it can be said that he has that controlling interest. Throughout Senator Douglas McClelland's speech there was the contrast between the Labor Party's approach and the Government's approach, but all I notice when I took at the Australian Labor Party Platform is that the Labor Party is not at all specific. I note that their 'blue book', which of course the Labor Party cannot depart from in any circumstances, slates: ti is necessary for government to regulate these areas in order to ensure that the public interest is protected, but as far as posible the traditional freedom of the Press should apply to radio and television.
So far I do not think that there would be any exception to be taken by the Government to that proposition. But then it states:

quote.para: The dual system of national and commercial radio and television is to continue. The tendency to monopoly is especially, dangerous and must be resisted, by appropriate legislation.

speech.para: I should think that that ls the same approach as the Government has adopted. The only difference is that the Government has brought into force what it regards as appropriate legislation. We are yet to hear from the Australian Labor Party what it would regard as appropriate legislation. One of the very real problems in this area is to determine when there is an interest in excess of that which is prescribed or determined. One does not play with words in saying that this is difficult to define. There is a practical problem in knowing when a person has a beneficial interest and when a person is subject to influence from or is prepared to act at the direction of another person. Notwithstanding all the efforts that can be made to ascertain the true position, sometimes we cannot obtain it.

Senator DouglasMcClelland referred to the Hendy case. That is a case which the Australian Broadcasting Control Board had examined. 1 am instructed that the Board has not been able to establish whether options were held by the Fairfax Company over the Hendy Company's interest in NBN. WIN, QTQ, CTC and DDQ. Replies were received, but they were not satisfactory to enable a decision to be made. Statutory declarations which were furnished to the licensee companies as required by the Act indicated that the shares were beneficially held by the 3 companies concerned. The terms of the Act are basically pointed towards beneficial ownership, which is necessarily a limited concept.

talk.start.para: - I take it that the Act does not require them to declare options.

- It does not require them to declare options. How does one determine whether an option exists and whether it is to be exercised? If it were to be exercised there would be a beneficial interest, but if it were not to be exercised it becomes irrelevant. That is one of the practical problems. Whilst I can accept much of what Senator Douglas McClelland has said, I do not think he has given due weight to the very real practical problems which are involved in making determinations of this character. I repeat only what I said earlier - that if appropriate legislation is to be introduced by the Labor Party to change this situation, if there is a real belief that (he legislation ought to be changed and the community protected, T am sure that the Government would be interested to know the terms of the appropriate legislation which the honourable senator has in mind.

speech.para: If one looks at the Elwood case, it would appear that the UIG Investments purchase in RVN is within the terms of the legislation. Originally Henderson Holdings, which had been owned by Mr R. A. G. Henderson, desired to buy RVN interests, but this was not possible because of television directorships which were held by Mr Henderson. Having regard to the provisions of the Act, UIG then applied for approval. Eleven statutory declarations were obtained by the Broadcasting Control Board from Mrs and Miss Henderson, the shareholders in UIG, and those declarations were to the effect that the shares in UIG were held beneficially by them. Senator Douglas McClelland is suspicious, but what is a board to do when it has s!atutory declarations from persons who state what the position is? In other circumstances, with other issues involved, I suggest that Senator Douglas McClelland would challenge immediately anyone who suggested that what a person had sworn on affidavit - possibly even not what he had sworn on affidavit but what he had told him - was not to be accepted, at least as prima facie truth. He would say that it should be accepted as true at least until some contrary evidence were given. I do not want to use (he expression 'double standards' because I have tried to be objective in this debate, but the problems are there and I think that Senator Douglas McClelland has not given adequate weight to them in his criticisms. Nor has he given adequate weight to the problems wilh which the Australian Broadcasting Control Board has to contend.

talk.start.para: - Where would Elwood, with a paid up capital of $4, gel sufficient capital to buy 210.000 shares?

- As the honourable senator said in the course of his address, it was probably borrowed - someone provided the money. I do not think it requires any imagination to believe that it was provided. But that is not the test which the Act lays down. The test is whether the shares are held by a person into whose hands they eventually come, under his title, or whether they are held by some person who is the beneficial owner. I mention these things only because as a matter of words and as a matter of language these are problems which I do not think are being given sufficient attention by Senator Douglas McClelland.

speech.para: In conclusion I say that the writing is on the wall for this legislation. I regret it because whilst it cannot be regarded as vital legislation, it was part of the housekeeping of government, tidying up the provisions of the legislation as experience has indicated that they may require to be tidied up. But if it is the wish of the Senate that even this housekeeping should be submitted to a Senate committee and it is the Senate's will that this be done, one must accept that the will of the Senate will prevail. The Government will oppose the amendment.

quote.para: That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Douglas McClelland's amendment) be left out.
