Senator MURPHY

talk.start.para: - This is a Bill to provide for the law of evidence in the Australian Capital Territory. I think that honourable senators are familiar with the background of the Bill. For the most part, evidence in the ACT had been dealt with by ordinance. The relevant ordinance was disallowed by the Senate towards the end of last year and a temporary Act was made providing in substance for the continuance of the provisions of the disallowed ordinance until the end of this month, March 1972. That was done because of the expressed view of the Senate that the law on this important topic ought to be made by Parliament itself and not be a matter of delegated legislation to be enacted in effect by the AttorneyGeneral. The matter has now come before the Senate and there is an opportunity to discuss in some detail the various provisions in the legislation in order that we may provide the best law of this important topic.

speech.para: As honourable senators will realise, the law of evidence applies to civil proceedings as well as to criminal proceedings and is an extremely important part of the law touching the rights of individuals. As such, we must pay a good deal of regard to it because decisions in cases often are determined by the provisions of the law of evidence. It affects the human rights of the persons who appear as parties or as witnesses in courts, whether in civil or criminal proceedings, and has always been the subject matter of a great deal of scholarships and often of a great deal of contention. The Bill here, as I understand it, does not purport to be a complete code of evidence for the law of the Territory. It deals, I would suggest, in substance with the statutory provisions which had been previously made. These were derived from the law of New South Wales. Indeed, certain Acts of New South Wales including the Evidence Act, the Royal Commissioners Evidence Act and the Witnesses Examination Act would cease to be in force in the Territory upon the enactment of this Bill.

One matter comes to mind immediately, lt is this: The question must be asked whether really there ought to be a law of evidence which applies generally to the Federal courts, that is, in their dealing in any event with the initial proceedings which come before them. Whatever the law of evidence is to be in the Australian Capital Territory, one would think that the same law ought to apply in courts such as the Commonwealth Industrial Court and the Federal Bankruptcy Court and in other Federal courts which may be established. Criticism has been expressed by judges and in other quarters that the decisions of the High Court of Australia itself may depend upon where a case is heard or. perhaps more importantly, where judgment is given, because the law to be applied in cases depends, under the Judiciary Act, upon the place where the proceedings are taking place or where the judgment is given, lt has been said, and T think rightly so, that the judgment given in Sydney on a case could be different to the judgment which would be given in Melbourne on the same case or vice versa. That is an extraordinary position. It is hardly consistent with the national conceptions with were crystallised at the time of Federation. It hardly seems right that evidenciary provisions should depend upon where a federal matter is being heard. To pitt it in simple terms: The Opposition takes the view that the rights of a citizen under federal law ought to be the same wherever he is and wherever his case is determined, and that we ought to be setting out to make our laws achieve that result, which they do not achieve at the moment.

We seem to be inclined to fit our federal laws on subjects such as' this into the interstices of the State laws. Perhaps an exam ple of that is the legislation which followed the Worthing case. This Parliament decided that the law to be applied to a Commonwealth place was the law of the Stale in which that Commonwealth place was situated. That means for instance that the' Commonwealth law which applies on the steps of the General Post Office in Melbourne is different to the Commonwealth, law which applies on the steps of the GPO in Sydney, if there is some activity which is an offence in Victoria but not an offence in New South Wales it means, in simple terms, that anyone who conducts that activity on the steps of the GPO in Melbourne is committing an offence but if someone conducts the same activity on the steps of the GPO in Sydney he is not committing an offence. That result was arrived at by the application of the law of this Parliament to Commonwealth places. Equally one has the situation of procedural matters and evidenciary matters varying from place to place. T suppose this has come about because it was thought that it would be more convenient to adopt this practice as the arm of the. Commonwealth did not stretch so far. In fact, there was some contention over many decades as to whether the State laws applied to such places as Commonwealth property. It may have' been for this reason that the attitude was adopted of not really preferring federal Jaw but of making it subordinate to the Slate law. We have accepted the procedural and, indeed, substantive provisions of State law and made them operate by virtue of our own enactments. lt seems to me to be a pity that we do not have a general enactment instead of one which applies merely to the Australian Capital Territory. However, insofar as it does apply to the Australian Capital Territry and insofar as some endeavour has been made to arrive at something which approaches a code, the Opposition welcomes this legislation. We welcome this attempt to get the law into some kind of order. It has not been satisfactory for one to have had to turn back to the provisions of the State enactments as if they were really incorporated by reference. That is not a satisfactory way in which to have our law operate. This situation is analogous to the sad state of our military law.
Even courts martial are unable to say really what our military law is because one has to look at the imperial law and then by examining various references endeavour to deduce the Australian law.

We have here legislation which deals with a large number of matters, civil and criminal, and the Opposition welcomes it. In saying that I do not mean that the Opposition agrees with all of the Bill. It contains certain provisions which the Opposition thinks are objectionable and some which the Opposition thinks require more explanation. There are also some as to which the Opposition is, frankly, quite dubious and there are some which it thinks are rather vague but which are of an experimental nature. I think we would be inclined to say that while certain provisions do not receive our blessing we would not offer any opposition because they are of an experimental nature and perhaps ought to be allowed to operate for a while in order to determine what difficulties will be encountered with them.

The Australian Labor Party, which hopes to bo in government soon, may seek to revise some of these measures in the light of experience. In saying that I should point out that I think that these matters are, for the most part, not of real party political difference in the ordinary sense. They are not matters on which one would fight an election. They are not matters on which one would appeal to the generality of people because, frankly, some of them are quite technical. But, despite the technicalities, the principles involved are of very great importance as they concern human rights. The Opposition hopes that anything it puts forward will be considered in the spirit of being able to assist in some way in improving this legislation, which, as I have said, is outside of the general run of great party political issues.

I wish to indicate some of the matters on which we would like further elucidation. I do not anticipate that this debate will conclude this evening. One of the matters about which there is some concern is clause 29 of the Bill. It deals with documentary evidence of facts in issue where the maker of the statement is not called as a witness. Would it be possible, before the commencement of the debate in Committee for a little more background material to be. supplied than was supplied during the second reading speech of the Minister? We are aware of the appearance of some of it in some of the English and Australian proceedings. But we question the width of its application or why it should be applied in criminal proceedings, and perhaps even in civil proceedings. The Opposition also questions whether the protection given in clause 31 is really wide enough. For instance, statements which might be important in a criminal trial might not be met by the scope of clause 31. In regard to clause 35, I suggest the inclusion of the word 'and' so that it reads:

item.para: . and/or was otherwise recognised by him as his statement.

speech.para: Perhaps the derivation of this could be given and also some consideration to whether that word ought properly in all the circumstances be included in such a provision. I am aware that in some cases this kind of expression has appeared elsewhere.

Clause 38 (2.) deals with the discretion of the judge to refuse to admit in evidence certain statements if he is satisfied that it would be unfair to the person charged to admit the statement in evidence. Perhaps some consideration might be given to whether the word 'would' is setting too high a test. I suggest the insertion of the word 'may' instead of 'would' because it might be difficult for a judge to say that he was satisfied that it would be unfair to the accused person. The test may be different if the judge said that it may be unfair to the accused person. If the accused is objecting the judge may be satisfied that it may be unfair to him whereas, if he has to be satisfied that it would be unfair, this might be setting a higher test than perhaps ought to be contained in such a provision. Dealing with the clauses relating to the admissibility of statements produced by computers, I question whether clause 45 really ought to be contained in the Bill, even if one takes the view that the part is unexplored, of an experimental nature and so forth. I question, even if it were to be passed in that fashion, whether a statement ought to be admissible notwithstanding the failure to comply with the relevant rules of court.

There are other matters, perhaps of a more important nature. They have been dealt with fairly fully by the AttorneyGeneral (Senator Greenwood) in his second reading speech. Those are the questions of compellability and the disclosure of communications made during marriage. 1 do not know whether it is useful to go through the arguments that might be put later. Certain problems arise in relation to these matters, lt seems to us that on the compellability of spouses and the disclosure of communications very great questions are raised which go beyond the evidence being given in a court in a civil pro.ceeding. Whether a spouse should be compelled to give evidence against the other spouse in a civil proceeding is an important question because technical rules are contained in the law of evidence and all through the law. Persons may obtain advantages or lose them through some technical rule. But in this case, we come up against the great principle of the relationship of spouses, lt occurs to me that perhaps some thought may be given to this matter in this place, lt seems terrible that as between husband and wife in a civil proceeding for the sake of some advantage someone can cause a wife to give evidence against her husband or a husband to give evidence against his wife, lt may be that the paramount public interest is better served by not requiring this to be done than by op:ning it up for the sake of some advantage which may be achieved.

talk.start.para: - It is only for the sake of competency. Surely you would not challenge that. A person is not compellable but he or she is competent; except in civil proceedings.
- The AttorneyGeneral is saying they are not compellable, but the fact is that under clause 54 (p.) they are compellable. The clause states:

quote.para: The wife or husband of a party to a proceeding (nor being a criminal proceeding) and the wife or husband of a person on whose behalf such a proceeding is prosecuted or defended is a competent and compellable witness in the proceeding-

speech.para: Sena' or Greenwood - If the honourable senator looks at. clause 66 he will see that it states: (I.) In a criminal proceeding, the person charged and the spouse of the person charged are competent witnesses but, except as provided by subsection (3.) of this section, the spouse is not a compellable witness.
I thought that the honourable senator was speaking about serious crimes.

talk.start.para: - No. When the Attorney-General interrupted I was talking about civil actions. He said they are not compellable but competent only. This Bill makes the spouse a compellable witness in a civil proceeding. This raises a question of the utmost public importance. It is a most serious matter to say that the relationship of the spouses should be invaded to the extent that a wife can be compelled against her will to go into the . witness box and give evidence against her husband. In certain circumstances that kind of thing may place a cloud over a marriage and put between the husband and the wife something that will last a lifetime. The dispute may be over a few hundred dollars or over a bill. The husband has given evidence. The wife is called. She has been outside the court. Not knowing what he said, she says: 'No, he did not say that' or 'He did say that'. That is the kind of situation which the law, as I understand it, has always endeavoured to avoid. The law has provided that they should not be put in that position. Whatever was the advantage or disadvantage in a. proceeding this was no! to be done. 1 will not add much on that matter. We say that the matter is a most serious one. We certainly will be giving attention 'o it later.
- Were not the provisions about which yon are complaining made law in the United Kingdom over 100 years ago? ls not that so in civil cases in respect of the competency and compellability of spouses?
- Is the AttorneyGeneral saying that for 100 years a spouse has been compelled to disclose communications made during the marriage?
- No. I referred only to civil proceedings. That was made law in England in 1851 and in New South Wales in 1852.

- Perhaps the AttorneyGeneral will get further information before the Committee stage is reached. We hope that further attention will be paid to that matter before then. It seems to us that very serious doubts are raised about the incrimination clause. Perhaps information may be obtained as to whether the certificate that is envisaged under clause 57 (5.) would protect a person against criminal proceedings under State law. If the Attorney-General is able to inform us now I would be pleased. If he is not, he can inform us at an early time. Perhaps he will tell us whether the certificate would extend to the spouse, and if not why not. It does not appear to do so. By that clause is it intended to protect a person against criminal proceedings under State law? If so. has any attention been given to whether the Commonwealth is competent to issue that certificate? It may be that the Commonwealth is competent. I think it probably is. Perhaps the Attorney-General could tell us. Perhaps he could also tell us whether any real protection is being given to a person against proceedings under State law. The admissibility or non-admissibility of evidence is one matter. Perhaps he could tell us how it is proposed that a person who would be forced to give incriminating answers which may open up the avenue to a prosecution of him would be protected so that the general principle of the law against self-incrimination can be preserved. Even if the answers are not admissible he may be exposed to a prosecution.

speech.para: As I have said on many other matters, the approach Ls not really a Party political approach. These are not matters on which elections are fought, but they are most important matters of human right. Some of these rights and privileges have been built up in the law. Some have a history extending over thousands of years. We on this side are most concerned that those rights and privileges should not be broken down without the most cogent reasons being given for the departure from what has hitherto been regarded as extremely important matters.

I refer now to clause 66 which touches on the subject of a compellable witness. Perhaps before we reach the Committee stage the Attorney-General will be able to give some attention to the matter and supply us with an answer as to the position of an accused person who wished, on his criminal trial, to call his spouse in his defence. Let us assume that the spouses are separated and are even hostile. Under this clause would a man on trial for his life be able to require his separated wife to give the evidence which might be necessary to save him from conviction? The clause states:

quote.para: In a criminal proceeding, the person charged and the spouse of the person charged are competent witnesses but, except as provided by subsection (3.) of this section, the spouse is not a compellable witness.

talk.start.para: - Is not this view inconsistent with the view that you were putting about the compellability in civil proceedings?

- Superficially it may appear to be so, but it is not. The paramount interest is the interest of the community in preserving the relationship between husband and wife. As I put it, I did not want the position to be that a wife could be called to give evidence against a husband, whether in a civil or a criminal proceeding. The view which I am suggesting tentatively is that she should not. 1 will put that another way. I will not be a chauvinistic male. One's spouse should not be able to be called to give evidence against one. I am suggesting that that principle can be preserved by ensuring that in civil proceedings she will not be compellable. I am suggesting that it can be preserved in criminal proceedings by providing that she will not be compellable at the instance of the prosecution. But it is perfectly consistent with that principle that she be compellable at the instance of the accused. The wife could be called to give evidence for the husband, or the husband for the wife. The calling in that case is a calling to give evidence in favour of the accused person. Have I resolved what appeared superficially to be an inconsistency?
- On the same reasoning a wife ought to be compellable to give evidence on behalf of her husband in a civil proceeding.

- If in a civil proceeding the situation has been reached that a wife will not, at the request of her husband, come to give evidence in that proceeding, then we. may say that the ground or reason for the public interest in maintaining this principle has disappeared. If they are at such odds that the wife is not even prepared to give evidence at the request of her husband, or vice versa, the relationship of the spouses is not being invaded; it has disappeared. The other clauses to which some attention might be given include clause 70, which relates to the introduction of the character of the accused. This again involves a very great principle of the law. The conditions under which the character of the accused should be able to be introduced by the prosecution are a matter of importance to all. We have some concern at the provisions that are included in that clause. Again, clause 74, which relates to comment on the failure to give evidence, seems to me at least to have a certain anomalous character, even though I am aware that in certain places the same provision exists.

speech.para: I have indicated some of the matters to which we will be giving attention during the Committee stage of consideration of the Bill. If the Attorney-General could supplement the extremely informative second reading speech by supplying us with further information on the clauses I have mentioned prior to the Committee stage being reached, we would be extremely grateful. I repeat that we welcome the Bill as an attempt to deal with these most important matters of the law of evidence. We realise that it is not a complete code. We are prepared to engage in a discussion of the detailed provisions of the Bill, some of which - only a few - we consider objectionable, others about which we have some doubt and others again of which we would like some further explanations. But on the whole we are pleased to have this Bill. We are pleased that the Senate saw fit to ensure that the legislation would not be delegated but would be covered by an Act of this Parliament. Therefore I indicate that the Opposition will not oppose the motion for the second reading of the Bill.

talk.start.para: - I have read with great interest the second reading speech of the AttorneyGeneral (Senator Greenwood) on this Bill and listened, also with great interest, to the comments of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Murphy). We in the Senate are privileged to have had the views of 2 leading members of the legal profession on this Bill. I am sure that at the Committee stage we will have an even more valuable discussion of some of its clauses. I agree with Senator Murphy that this Bill is really dealt with much more appropriately by discussion in Committee than by a second reading debate. The Attorney-General, in his second reading speech, for the lay members of the Senate has canvassed very extensively the nature of the law of evidence, its purpose and the many changes that are made to it in respect of the Australian Capital Territory. The case which is made out by the Attorney-General and which basically is accepted by the Opposition, as expressed by Senator Murphy, indicates that this measure is a salutary one which was long overdue in the Australian Capita] Territory.

speech.para: Whether the changes that are made really justify a debate in the Senate or whether they could have been achieved appropriately by an ordinance is a matter that we have debated already at some length. For my own part, I believe that the changes included in this Bill are of such a character that they are merely bringing the law of the Territory up to date. There are not many major changes from the basic law of evidence as accepted throughout Australia. There are one or two. and I propose to mention them in the course of my remarks.

By and- large, this Bill becomes necessary because the law of evidence of the Australian Capital Territory was extraordinarily outmoded and far behind the law as it existed and as it has developed in the State jurisdications. There are very good examples of that in the Attorney-General's second reading speech. Tt is interesting, for instance, to note the changes in the law relating to hearsay evidence as far as hearsay statements in documents are concerned. When I was in the Western Australian Parliament several years ago I had occasion to introduce a measure to apply the English Evidence Act of 1938 to the Western Australian law. At that time I thought we were the last State in Australia - as indeed we were - to adopt the English legislation. I think that measure was introduced into the Western Austraiian Parliament in 1967 - 29 years behind the times. 1 thought that was a rather sad state of affairs. So I was rather shocked to find that the Australian Capital Territory was even more behind the times than Western Australia was.

talk.start.para: - Has it made any difference to you?

- It has. It has also made some difference to one or two cases in which I have been counsel, I am thankful to say. That is only an example of the extent to which we are behind the times. In New South Wales, which has taken the great leap forward into 1875 or thereabouts, perhaps it does not seem to be so bad. It seemed to me that in respect of a measure which had been accepted in the United Kingdom nearly 30 years before and which had worked successfully there we should have done a little better than that in Australia. However, there are a number of other very outmoded provisions in the laws of this Territory. Another feature is the competence and compellability of witnesses, particularly the spouses of parties. Senator Murphy has already made some quite interesting comments on this matter. One of the most outmoded rules which, of course, has been altered here, is the rule known as Russell and Russell which prevented evidence being given by a spouse of non-access and which would have the effect of bastardising a child of the marriage. I think that that rule went out of effect in the United Kingdom as far back as 1924. This rule arose out of the fact - if my memory serves me correctly - that people who had served in the First World War and who had come back had found that their family had increased by several children but that they were unable to obtain dissolution of the marriage on the basis that they had been away from home for 3 or 4 years. They had to have other evidence to prove that the child or children of the marriage were not their own. Of course this serves to indicate what an absurd provision that was. However, this still seems to be the law in the Australian Capital Territory. I am very pleased to find that 50 years or thereabouts later we are bringing the law of this Territory into some semblance of common sense.

speech.para: In my view the nature of this Bill is to be commended. When one reads of the attention, care and thought which has been put into it and the people who have been consulted in regard to it one expects that it would have this character. For instance, I notice that the Bill has been the subject of study for some 3 years by a committee presided over by Mr Justice Fox of the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court. But the assistance he has been given and the consultants who have been engaged in relation to this measure do make impressive reading. This is detailed at the end of the Attorney-General's speech. In particular the Bill has been considered by and comments received from no less an authority on the law of evidence than Dr Rupert Cross of Oxford University. I think that honourable senators with a legal background will recognise him as the outstanding legal authority on the law of evidence. Perhaps some of the clarity and wording of this Bill may be due to his great facility for clear legal expression and exposition. Apart from such general comments on the proposals which I applaud it is clear from the character of the legislation, particularly the part relating to law of hearsay evidence that this Bill represents the most up-to-date thinking on the subject. Whether one necessarily agrees with the way in which it is treated is another matter but certainly this Bill gives repeated evidence of having received the consideration and treatment which one would expect from the people listed who have been engaged in its preparation.

Of course the question arises from a first consideration of a Bill on the law of evidence as to whether in this day and age we should bother about having a law of evidence at all. The Attorney-General in his speech does advert to some modern thinking in legal circles that there is no need for a law of evidence. Whatever the position may have been in the past and whatever the justification for technical rules on admissibility of evidence there may have been, in view of the greater sophistication, literacy and so forth of jurors - apart from judges - it is believed there is no need to have any technical rules relating to the admissibility of evidence. Some people believe that all we really need these days is a general provision that whatever is relevant to the proceedings is admissible. We should be concerned not with the admissibility of evidence but only with the weight which is to be attached to it. Although that might be a respectable approach to the problem, 1 do suggest that there still needs to be some rules which, traditionally, have been dealt with under the law of evidence. Such an approach may well eliminate all the rules relating to hearsay evidence. Of course this Bill before us does have quite a number of provisions which deal with the exclusion of hearsay evidence as a general rule. But we would still need to have rules relating to what is generally called the 'facilitation of proof. That is the way in which certain things can be more easily proved. I refer particularly to proof of signature of officials, public documents and so on. We would need to have some rules relating to evidence by infants and the swearing of infants. We would need to have some rules relating to the protection of witnesses. I think it is clear that undoubtedly there is need for some rules relating to evidence in our legal system.

I agree wilh the Attorney-General and with the basis of this Bill that perhaps the time has not arrived when we could adopt this more radical approach and say that we need only the law of evidence along the lines which I have been discussing. It is true that steps in this direction are rapidly gaining pace, particularly in the United Kingdom. But I would prefer to see a longer experiment with some of the relaxations of the present rules, particularly those relating to the exclusion of hearsay evidence. I suggest that we wait a little longer before we try anything more radical. Like Senator Murphy all I seek to do in the second reading debate on this Bill is to consider what one might call 'certain highlights' of the measure and leave a more detailed consideration until the Committee stages. That becomes inevitable because it is not a measure with which we commonly deal. It is not a measure which has behind it some principle which can be debated at the second reading stage, leaving the detailed work for discussion at the Committee stages. The whole of this Bill, apart from the basic question of whether or not we need a law of evidence, deals really with a number of detailed and quite separate measures. Therefore it is an extremely difficult subject to discuss in a speech at the second reading stage.

However, there are one or two major provisions of the Bill which probably do impinge upon some pretty basic rights which could be the subject of useful discussion at this stage. For reasons which I have given already I entirely support the provisions of the Bill which deal with the extension of admissibility to statements in documents. As I have said already this seems to me only to be bringing the law here into line with that which has applied in the United Kingdom and the States of Australia for many years. It does so in a way which obviously takes account of the experience of practice under the English Evidence Act of 1938. As a matter of fact, it seems to be following very much experience we had in Western Australia when we adopted that legislation in 1967. So I can say only how much I agree with the way in which that approach is made in this Bill.

However, a very considerable, and of course interesting, extension of the hearsay rule is proposed in relation to the admissibility of documents produced by computers. I gather that this is a fairly novel extension of the rule, although I think the Attorney-General said it had been adopted in Victoria. I do not know to what extent or when it was adopted; at all events, it would not be a very long experience.

talk.start.para: - It would be in the last six or nine months.
- But it is in force, I gather.
- It has been introduced to the Parliament.

- So it is a little early for us to say just what effect this category of admissibility will have. Of course, on the face of it it seems a fairly sensible extension which is applied much along the lines as statements in documents - documents which have come into existence by people who have no axe to grind, so to speak, when the document comes into existence. On the face of it, the document - in this case the product of a computer - should have every resemblance of persuasiveness and reasonableness about it. I notice that some of the restrictions placed on the admissibility of the document produced by the computer are that the computer must have been working properly and it must have been operated in the ordinary course of the activity and so on of the person who was using it. In this broad sense I think it is only sensible that the documents produced by a computer should be admissible. However, I can foresee that there could be serious objections to the production of evidence from a computer. The admissibility of evidence provision is stated in the broadest terms in clause 42 <1.) of the Bill. It states: . . a statement contained in a document produuced by a computer is . . . admissible as evidence of the facts stated in the document if those facts are facts of which direct oral evidence would be admissible.

speech.para: Presumably, of course, the oral evidence of the facts is given by a person with personal knowledge of them. One can visualise the use of computers by police forces. In the course of police work a great deal of information could be fed into computers quite properly in the course of an investigation. But, of course, one could readily imagine how highly damaging and highly improper it would be for such evidence suddenly to become admissible at a criminal trial simply because it had been processed through a computer. I would like to hear the Attorney-General's comments on this aspect of the matter. It is a subject in relation to which, as I said, we have not had any experience in practice in this country. Really I do not know whether any experience has been obtained anywhere in the world. For my own part 1 would like to see a little more discretion provided in the judge to exclude this evidence, particularly in criminal proceedings. 1 have in mind the general discretion that is given to a court to refuse to admit statements in documents. Clause 38 (2.) states:

quote.para: In a criminal proceeding, the judge may refuse to admit in evidence ... a statement in a document tendered in evidence if he has reason to doubt the reliability of the document or is satisfied that it would bc unfair to the person charged to admit the statement in evidence. 1 cannot see any quite similar provision under Part VII of this Bill which deals with the admissibility of documents produced by computers. I think there is some need for a safeguard in this situation. I know that some discretions are given for the admissibility of these documents. Clause 43 (1.) states: . . if it has reason to doubt the authenticity of a document ... or the accuracy of the information contained in such a document . . .

speech.para: But that is not quite the point that I have in mind. I have in mind a sort of general discretion that the judge may exercise if he feels that it will be unfair to the person charged, as is provided under clause 38.

talk.start.para: - It would have to be a circumstance where unfairness would arise from something other than lack of authenticity or lack of accuracy. That may be difficult to establish in the case of a document.

- Except that I have in mind the situation where evidence is coming into the hands of the police and the police are computerising a lot of information preparatory to using it in a criminal charge. I would not think in the ordinary course of events that the prosecution would produce that type of evidence, but if it were produced I think it would be most improper for that evidence to go forth at a criminal trial and that a judge should have that sort of discretion in relation to it. 1 turn now to the question of the competence and compellability of spouses. Senator Murphy has made some interesting comments on this question. It is true that what this Bill seeks to do on this subject is simply to bring the law of the Australian Capital Territory into line with what has been the experience in the United Kingdom and other parts of Australia for many years; namely, to make parties and the spouses of parties competent and compellable witnesses in civil proceedings, to make them competent witnesses in criminal proceedings, and compellable witnesses in certain criminal proceedings. 1 am not presenting myself as an authority on the law in every State of Australia but for my part there is an extension in this Bill in that it makes a spouse compellable to disclose communications made with the other spouse during the marriage. I think that might be the real ground of Senator Murphy's objection. He did not put it in that limited way, I know; he put it in a broader context.
- I think that is an additional ground.

- The way in which Senator Murphy put it was that a spouse should not be compelled to give any evidence against the other partner of the marriage. This is not the sort of protection which has existed, the- only protection being in relation to statements made between the spouses. The old traditional provision has great merit on the line that

speech.para: Senator Murphymentioned that is, for the preservation of the secrecy and the inviolability of the marriage relationship. I am old fashioned enough to believe that there is a lot of merit in that protection. I know it has been adversely commented on by no less a person than Lord Reid whom the Attorney-General quoted and who, when speaking in the House of Lords, indicated some of the deficiencies of that protection. I think we should give some consideration to this on the general lines of protecting the basic inviolability of the marriage relationship, at all events when the parties are living together.

Before leaving the question of witnesses generally I feel that clauses 60 and 61, which deal with discrediting one's own witness, leave this problem in a somewhat unsatisfactory state. It is a very sound general rule of the law of evidence that if one calls a witness to prove a particular fact and that witness fails to do so or proves the contrary to be the case one can call other witnesses to establish that fact. In that sense, one can contradict one's own witness. What the law has set its face against is a person discrediting his own witness in the same way that one can discredit an opponent's witness, that is, by cross-examining the witness about what he says, and suggesting that he is not telling the truth or that he is mistaken or forgetful. The most damaging way of attacking him is to prove that on other occasions he has made statements inconsistent with his present testimony, whether in writing or verbally. Another method of attacking a witness, although it is not often adopted by counsel and it has very great dangers attached to it, is to attack the person's reputation and credit generally or to try to establish that he is not to be believed because he has a criminal record or a reputation for untruthfulness and so on.

It has always seemed to me that the law on this subject is unnecessarily complicated. It has always been clear that one can call other evidence to contradict what has been said. If the first witness says that something is not a fact, you can bring along another witness to say that it is. That has nothing to do with discrediting the particular witness directly. I think it is basically sound to say that if you call a witness you should not be able in one breath to call him a witness of truth and in the next breath to attack him on his credibility.

talk.start.para: - You cannot approbate and reprobate.

- Yes. You cannot do that to show that he is not someone who ought to be believed or could be believed. I have always believed that if a witness comes into court to prove a certain fact and he does not prove it but proves the reverse although he has made a statement to the contrary, there should not be any real difficulty about not only proving the statement that he made previously but also cross-examining him about that statement. A witness may make a statement identifying a particular person or about the existence of a particular set of facts. One might want to use the ordinary techniques of cross-examination and ask him questions as to the when, how, and why of the circumstances surrounding the evidence he gave. Glauses 60 and 61, as I understand them, try to facilitate cross-examination in those circumstances but to my mind they do not do so very clearly. When we come to the Committee stage I propose to say more about those, clauses.

speech.para: I am a little disappointed about Part X of the Bill which relates to evidence in criminal proceedings. 1 refer particularly to the proof of convictions against an accused person. As the Attorney-General clearly set out in his second reading speech, there simply has to be a very considerable degree of protection of an accused person in a criminal trial against any evidence being given or any cross-examination being conducted concerning his previous convictions or conduct because of the damaging effect this would have on the question of his innocence or guilt. But an accused person forfeits this right in certain circumstances. One of those circumstances is when he seeks to rely on his good character as a ground of defence. If an accused person tries to make out that he did not commit a particular act because he could not have done so if regard was had to his good character, naturally he could not be allowed to retain that appearance of good character if he had a string of convictions.

Another ground, which has been in existence in England since 1898, gives rise to a great deal of difficulty in criminal trials. I refer to the situation in which he is said to lose this protection if the nature or conduct of his defence is such as to involve imputations on t'-e character of the prosecutor or witnesses for the prosecution. There is a whole host of case law which reveals the defects in applying this provision and the many cases where real injustice has been worked on the accused who has been hampered in presenting his defence, no doubt even in respect of matters of substantive fact in relation to the charge. Although it has nothing to do with his character or the character as such of the prosecutor, indirectly the character of the prosecutor is affected. Senator Byrne who perhaps has had personal experience of this type of situation would probably agree with me. I must say that personally 1 have not had much experience of this because .1 have not had much experience in the criminal jurisdiction. However, I know from academic and other discussion that this is ft very difficult provision. I would have liked something a little more up to date included in this legislation.

The only other matter that 1 wish to mention in general on the Bill is the very modern provision which has been adopted in England, although I do not know how far it has been adopted throughout the States of Australia. I refer to the rule which provides that in a civil proceeding, in order to prove a particular fact, one can admit evidence of a conviction which necessarily involves the establishment of that fact. This is known in legal jargon as overturning the rule in Hollington v. Hewthorne. In everyday experience it covers the situation in which a person is being sued for damages for negligence, probably in a running-down case, and the defendant has been convicted by a traffic court for negligent driving on the same facts as the plaintiff has sought to establish as the basis of this claim for damages. Until now that evidence of his conviction for negligent driving has not been admissible in the claim for damages, but under this Bill it is proposed that the conviction for negligent driving should be admissible in the civil court in the claim for damages. On the face of it this seems to be a reasonable enough proposition.

No doubt a judge hearing the claim for damages would, in most cases, not pay much attention to the conviction in a lower court because, as we all know, people summonded on 'a charge of negligent driving, or a lower category of case which they have in Western Australia, although 1 do not know- about the other States, known as careless driving, or perhaps failing to give way to the right, often do nol bother lo appear before the court. There is a whole gamut of traffic offences, ali or any of which could be used to establish negligence on the part of a defendant in a civil case. As we all know, in many of these cases the defendant when charged in the tra flic court does not bother to go along to the court or to put in a pica, or he puts in a p,en of guilty because he thinks it is an easy way out and will save him employing a lawyer and perhaps save costs. He might even think that he would be more leniently treated if he wrote lo the court with a long p'ea of his own, pleading guilty and putting forward some exculpatory comment.

So J suggest thai it is perfectly clear that the circumstances in which a person is convicted in a traffic court have very little bearing on the question of his civil liability. Again. 1 have been conservative and old-fashioned enough to believe that the case of Hollington v. Hewthorne had considerable merit in it. However, it is now to be overturned in this legislation. I do pot think it is worth while making any great issue about it, but I would like simply to record that the case to which I have referred seems to have some merit in it. I should think that in practice, although we now make the convictions admissible, in fact they will have very little bearing upon the decision which a judge would make on the same facts in a civil claim.

talk.start.para: - It is almost like bringing in a criminal conviction in an estoppel situation, lt is not generally admissible.
- It is not a matter of estoppel.
- ft is not between the same parties.

- That is so. The only other matter on which I wanted to comment is one that I mention because it has a considerable interest generally so far as laymen are concerned. That is the provisions of the Bill concerning confessions. I was a little surprised when Senator

speech.para: Murphy did not mention this because the Bill does not alter the rules hitherto governing the admissibility of confessions. This measure provides for the admissibility of confessions in certain circumstances in which they would have been excluded under common law. I refer to clause 68.

talk.start.para: - Does the honourable senator support a confession obtained under threat as being admissible?
- The honourable senator is referring to a point that I was about to lead up to. Sub-clause (2.) provides:

quote.para: A confession or admission tendered in evidence against tie person charged in a criminal proceeding shall not be rejected only on the ground that a promise or other inducement, or a threat (not being the exercise of violence, force or other form of compulsion), has been held out to or exercised upon the person making the confession or admission, if the judge is satisfied that the means by which the confession or admission was obtained were not in fact likely to cause an untrue confession or admission to be made.

speech.para: The reason for this modification of the existing rule is that there has been a very highly technical administration of the existing law in relation to an inducement, a threat or a promise. Many confessions have been rendered inadmissible because of a very highly technical interpretation of what is a threat or an inducement. For instance, if my memory serves me rightly, it is all right to say to a person: 'Be sure to tell the truth', or 'Make sure you are telling the truth', or something like that, even when expressed in quite firm language, but if one were to say to a person: You had better tell the truth', that would be inadmissible because of the use of the word 'better', that being perhaps an inducement or a threat. I mention this as an example for Senator Cavanagh's benefit.

talk.start.para: - Would it not be better to define a threat or promise?
- I do not think that can be done. The way in which the Bill approaches the problem gives the judge a discretion.

That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: - I crave the indulgence of the Senate at this hour to ventilate a matter that I feel is important enough to protest about because I think that a speedy investigation of the facts should be carried out by the respective departments concerned and an explanation provided. I raise the matter also so that my remarks will be recorded in Hansard for future research.

speech.para: In August 1971 the Government of Colombia extended an invitation to the Prime Minister's Department for Australia to participate in the First International Handicrafts Exhibition to be held at Narino from 4th January to 10th January 1972. Invitations were issued to other nations also. As I said, the invitation was received in August. On 17th November 1971 - 3 months later - a copy of the letter was received by the Premier's Department in Queensland. Honourable senators should remember that this exhibition was to be held from 4th January to 10th January 1972. Yet, on 17th November 1971, 3 months after the invitation had been received by the Australian Government, it was forwarded to the Premier's Department in Queensland. I take it that it was sent to appropriate departments in other States.

The Queensland Premier's Department processed the letter to the Queensland Department of Education. From then on, the letter was handled by the Director of Cultural Affairs in Queensland who wrote to the Government of Colombia and asked it for a list of the conditions which would be required to be met by intending applicants. A list of conditions was received together with 6 application forms. The Director of Cultural Affairs immediately sought out 6 people living in or around Brisbane. He did this because of the time factor. He sought people whom he thought were of sufficient standard to be able to be exhibitors at an international level. He forwarded a letter to 6 people who had been selected. Four of them replied that they would be interested in being applicants.

Among the applicants was Mrs Lillian Bosch of Surfers Paradise. Mrs Lillian Bosch is no ordinary run-of-the-mill art exhibitor. She is a woman of international fame in the arts. She is a former American who migrated to Surfers Paradise about 3 years ago. She has established there, at a cost of $500,000, an art centre. She is a relatively young woman and is continuing to improve the art centre. It is reasonable to assume that, in her lifetime, this art centre may be worth approximately $1.5m. The reason why I am laying emphasis on the cost of the art centre is that Mrs Lillian Bosch has willed it to the Commonwealth of Australia. I ask honourable senators to remember that this art centre already has been willed to the Commonwealth of Australia as this, in the light of what I will disclose later on, will provide a most interesting comparison between her generosity and the generosity of the Government to which she has been so kind.

I will not weary honourable senators by giving them a long run-down on the reputation or the talents of Mrs Bosch. Let me point out, however, that the Australian News and Information Bureau Office in New York on 18th October 1971 issued a bulletin in which it devoted 3i columns to the reputation of Mrs Lillian Bosch as an artist of international fame. In the concluding paragraph, the bulletin states:

quote.para: She says she has made provisions in her will for the Surfers Paradise Cultural Centre to be left to the Australian Government in the hope that it will become an internationally known centre of culture.

speech.para: As I said, I do not wish to give the Senate a tedious account of the details of this bulletin. I ask for leave to incorporate it in Hansard.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT- Is leave granted? There being no objection, leave is granted. (The document read as follows):

debateinfo.title: HAVEN-BORN A'RTIST SUPPORTS CULTURE IN AUSTRALIA

debate.para: The concrete jungles of spaceage man seem worlds away to Winter Haven-born artist Lillian Hodnett Bosch.
These days, as she strolls relaxed and content along the while, surf-washed beaches of Australia's Gold Coast, she finds it difficult to believe that they exist at all.
At last,' she says, '1 have found peace.'
In November 1968, she was almost at her wits end after 12 months of relentless globe-trotting to escape from the traumas of modern living.
Finally, she landed at Brisbane airport with a vague notion that the Great Barrier Reef might prove to be her Shangri-la.
She was startled to learn from a cab driver that the reef was still another 500 miles or so further north.
OK,' she said, 'take me to the nearest beach.'
But lady', he replied, 'that's 55 miles away.'
I don't care,' she said, 'take me!'
So, Lillian Bosch 'discovered' Surfers Paradise, the glamor surfing beach resort on Australia's Gold Coast.

I just sank into the warm sand . . . and haven't moved since,' she says. She has certainly moved to establish herself in Surfers Paradise. She now owns 3 prime beach-front properties with a 150 ft frontage to the Pacific Ocean, is buying up several more around her and has re-designed one beachfront home into a fascinating series of intimate galleries. Nor do her plans stop there, she is midway through construction of what she claims will be Australia's first privately-owned international cultural centre.
As the dollars pour out from her real estate interests along the Gulf of Mexico, she ploughs them into this venture of a lifetime. So far. her cultural dream' has cost around $500,000.

She has walled-in a huge rear-section of the three beachfront properties, and is turning it into a natural art setting. She plans an intimate gallerycumtheatre in a garden setting with freeform pool, huge boulders, mosses, tree ferns and waterfalls.
The centre also will produce 16mm films of artists-craftsmen at work to build up a large film and slide library of the arts.
Lillian plans to invite internationally known artists and craftsmen for brief workshop sessions with Australians in similar fields.
This will become an international centre for fine artists-craftsmen,' she says. 'They can work here in the best possible atmosphere, and pass on some of their knowledge to others.'
She also wants to make a move of life as she sees it on the sands outside her front window; the people, the surf, the fishermen, the sunsets, the tiny crabs.
Ecology, conservation and preservation of the balance of nature play a major role in Lillian Bosch's thinking and art.
She has recently developed a passion for Australian aboriginal arts and crafts, and has several fine examples of bark paintings and carvings from central and northern Australia.
Tn the mornings, usually around daybreak, she strolls along the cool deserted beach, picking up shells, seaweed, driftwood, anything, she says, that looks like 'interesting aft material.'
On hot days she holds business conferences, interviews and art discussions in her pool.
We just stand in the water , up to our necks and yak,' she says.
Tn this climate it beats sitting around a table.'

She also owns 800 acres' of dense rain forest at Springbrook, the natural mountain backdrop to the Gold Coast. " Springbrook is her 'ultimate retreat',' and she goes there when she .wants to think, read and paint.
Lillian Bosch was born in Winter Haven, 47 years ago, the daughter of pioneer citrus grower James Victor Hodnett.

She attended Traphagen School and the Arts Student League in New York and Sophie Newcomb Art School of Tulane University, New Orleans. Her B.S. degree was received at the University of Tampa, and her graduate work was at Florida State University with Karl Zebre

Internationally-known painters with whom she studied include Rene Bouche, Maurice Kantor, Theodore Stamos and Stuart Brisley. She also has studied paintmaking, sculpture, weaving, tapestry, ceramics, pouring stainless steel and other crafts.
In 1965 she exhibited in the Redfern Gallery, London, and at the Four Arts Society Exhibition, West Palm Beach.

In 1970, her works were included in the Gold Coast Prize Exhibition; the Perth Drawing Show; and the Metarco Gallery, New York; Lidums Gallery, Adelaide; America House (World Craft Council), New York; the Queensland Art Gallery; the University of Queensland.
This year she held a one-man show at Macquarie Galleries, Canberra.
She has been married three times and has lived in Mexico, Spain, Morocco, France, Italy, Denmark, Canada and England.
One marriage left her with a legacy of 3,000 acres of land on the Gulf of Mexico. When land values boomed in the 1960s Lillian Bosch could afford to 'do her own thing.'
Above all else, Lillian Bosch intends to develop her cultural project
She says she has made provisions in her will for the Surfers Paradise Cultural Centre to be left to the Australian Government in the hope that it will become an international-known centre of culture.
Honourable senators will see that Mrs Lilian Bosch, one of the applicants from Queensland who was prepared to accept the invitation to this exhibition, is an artist of international standard.

As I have said, the Queensland Director of Cultural Activities, Mr Creedy, cabled the Government of Colombia and received application forms which he sent to 6 people. Among some of the requirements of the Colombian Government regarding intending applicants were the provisions that:

quote.para: Exhibits which are sent by Government Offices and Agencies, either official or semi-official, will be accepted. Exhibits from Private Firms must have the authorisation of Government concerned.
It is recommended that each participating Nation send a Delegate as its representative to the first International Handicraft Exhibition.
Two exhibits from each country, chosen by that country, will become the property of Plastic Arts Section of the Casa de la Cultura de Narino

Each participating country should send its National Flag, typical costumes (both male and female) of any region of the country and also any literature and souvenirs which it considers apt, in addition to its handicrafts.

debate.para: Honourable senators will admit that those requirements are not very onerous.

Mr Creedycirculated this information and, as I said, 4 applicants, including Mrs Lillian Bosch, accepted. I was then approached by Mrs Bosch. She said that she would need to make arrangements to depart by Qantas on 24th December 1971 if she was to participate in the international exhibition. She asked whether I could assist her by pointing out to the Australian Government that she was an accredited delegate or representative of the Queensland Government. I have a letter here which the Queensland Government sent to her and to the Government of Colombia accrediting her as an official Queensland representative and as the leader of Queensland's delegation.

On 17th December 1971, I telephoned the office of the Minister for the Environment, Aborigines and the Arts, the Hon. Peter Howson, M.P., to ask him to give urgent attention to this matter. His secretary said that the matter was urgent as it was 17th December and these people were due to depart on 24th December. My request was taken down over the telephone. I dictated the information over the telephone. Two days later I had received no communication. Then I was asked to submit my request in writing. In the letter which I wrote, I asked:

item.para: Could the way be cleared with Customs for the exhibition pieces Mrs Bosch will be carrying, both out of and back into Australia, bearing in mind she will have left two pieces at the exhibition. (Approximate value of these two pieces is $300 and $200 respectively.)
Could Mrs Bosch be provided with a National Flag.
Could Mrs Bosch be provided with literature on Australia, an amount of, say, a small travel bag.

Could Mr Creedy's letter to the Officer in Charge of the Exhibition be supported by a letter from you giving Mrs Bosch Australian representation at the Exhibition. The address is - Officer in Charge, First International Handicrafts Exhibition, Casa de la Cultura. de Narino, Apartado Aereo No. 794, Pasto, Narino, Columbia, South America.

ls there a possibility of notification to the Australian Ambassador at Brazil, whom it \ is understood visits Columbia as part of his duties, wilh a view to his giving any possible assitance to Mrs Bosch.

debate.para: On 22nd December the Minister for the Environment, Aborigines and the Arts replied in the following terms:

quote.para: I refer to your letter of 1 7th December about an International Handicrafts Exhibition to be held in Colombia, South America, from 4th-10:h January 1972.

Although I am afraid that I am unable to provide Mrs L. Bosch wilh a letter conferring representative status, I shall arrange for your other requests to be brought to the attention of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet

debate.para: Which got the letter in the first place - (in respect of the Flag), Foreign Affairs, Customs and Excise and the News and Information Bureau, in order that they may provide whatever asstance is practicable. I have also asked that they communicate wilh you direct.

It is now 7th March 1972 and as yet I have not heard from any of the organisations mentioned. Incidentally, nothing more has been heard of the matter. Mrs Bosch went to Colombia at her own expense. She was appointed a judge of a crafts section at the exhibition and was invited to be and accepted the position of a judge of a major festival associated with the Colombia activities. She was given warm and hospitable treatment by a wide variety of influential Colombian people who recognised her great talents.

Here is the punch line. Mrs Lillian Bosch returned from Colombia, South America, on 24th January. She brought back with her a special international trophy which was awarded for the work she exhibited at the international exhibition and a second trophy which was awarded for work exhibited by Frances Wildt of Brisbane, who accompanied Mrs Bosch. Colombia will stage another exhibition in 2 years' time. The last exhibition, which was the first one ever conducted, was attended by 10 countries, all from the Southern Hemisphere. The standard of the exhibition was very high and the outside interest in it was obvious. The number of countries which will be participating in 2 years' time could easily be double if not treble the number which participated on this occasion. It was a major planned showing and was run in conjunction with local Indian festivals which highlighted the excellent local crafts, especially weaving and wood carving. The festival associated with the exhibition called on the participating countries each to be represented in the parade. The national flag of the country was required to be carried in that parade, national dress or representative costume displayed and the national flag hung in the Casa del Cultura during the 10 days of the exhibition. What a shame to Australia that Mrs Bosch did not have a flag of her own country! The Colombian authorities obtained an encyclopaedia and provided an artist to draw a picture of the Australian flag for the people to see. They also entered a float representing Australia in the festival procession, but as there was no supply available of national material they did their best by fitting out a float with make-believe Australians on it. These people were dressed something like wild colonials strongly influenced by South American Indians.

As the invitation to participate in this exhibition arrived in Australia in August 1970 it is surprising that, between them, the Department of Foreign Affairs, the Department of the Environment, Aborigines and the Arts, the Australian Tourist Commission, the News and Information Bureau and the Department of Trade and Industry could not come up with enough basic display material for shipment to Colombia so that Australia could be presented as we like to think of ourselves. Mrs Bosch said the exhibition was important and she believes that it is important for Australian crafts that we be represented at every international exhibition to which we are invited. She has shown her willingness to attend far away places, talk Australian craft on an international level and give her valuable work to remain in overseas countries to bring admiration to Australian skills.

Perhaps the lesson to be learned from the dreadful exercise of the Colombian exhibition is that the Commonwealth Government should be able to assist people like Lillian Bosch in the same manner as it assists sportsmen to attend government sponsored or official international competitions. IV might even be said that Australia could do well to aid financially Mi s Bosch, or people like her, to get to foreign countries by way of Qantas Airways Ltd.

Incidentally, Mrs Bosch has assisted the Commonwealth of Australia to the extent of half a million dollars. These people most certainly must be supported by way of accreditation, status and official recognition. We must also ease their departure and re-entry problems.

I believe that this matter calls for an urgent top level inquiry and an explanation to the Senate, Mrs Bosch and the Queensland Government. The Commonwealth has shown a lack of responsibility and gratitude to and interest in a woman who has already willed a half-million dollar art centre to the people of Australia. I shall let the matter rest there and look forward to the Minister's co-operation in having the matter fully investigated and explained.

talk.start.para: - Having listened to the speech of Senator McAuliffe I would hate to let the opportunity pass without paying tribute to the News and Information Bureau for the co-operation I have received from it. On every occasionI have approached it and sought material for use on an overseas trip or in a particular circumstance the News and Information Bureau has co-operated immediately and fully. In situations where I have wished to have an Australian flag available I have received nothing but cooperation from the Department of Education and Science--
- The honourable senator is suggesting that assistance is given only to Liberal members of the Parliament.

-I am simply saying that there are various ways in which one goes about doing things and there are all sorts of factors involved, but I have received nothing but co-operation from the departments and organisations mentioned by Senator McAuliffe.I do not wish to enter into a political debate. Nor doI wish to discuss whether Senator McAuliffe should have received a better response from the Ministers or departments he mentioned. I am simply defending certain public servants who impliedly have been attacked this evening and whose co-operation I have always found to be outstanding.

- As this appearsto be a night of confessions. I have decided to put my position on record. When the Lions Club of Australia made application to the Prime Minister (Mr McMahon) for a flag to be taken to an international conference in Japan it was told by the Prime Minister that flaps were available only to schools and boy scouts.
- All I can do is promise that Senator McAuliffe's remarks will be drawn to the attention of the appropriate Ministers.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
